div1.head: Civil War Pocket Diaries of William H. Smith

Wm. H. Smith
Prisoner of War
Camp Sumpter
Andersonville
Georgia

William H. Smith
Company E
7th Michigan Vol.
div1.p:
POCKET
DIARY
1864
PUBLISHED ANNUALLY
FOR THE TRADE
1864.

div3.p: A very pleasant day no news as yet of any exchange two or three men get was -hed to day because they are dirty and filthy. The first (First) of January I ever remember of seeng with-out snow on the ground I took tea one year ago to-day at Horace Hubbards some difference from my meal this evening.

div3.head: Saturday 2
div3.p: This morning is very cold the water pipes are froze up got our water to day from the canal we get only one meal. I write down the names of those who the Dr vaccinates pass of the time in play-ing poker for pins No news of exchanges{2}

div3.head: Monday, February 1
div3.p: I am so lame this morning that I can scarsely walk it rains is rather colder - again no trade to day only a few loavs of bread & some pies the boys are playing cards for fun.

div3.head: Tuesday, February 2, 1864.
div3.p: Clark only gets 4 loaves of bread this morning. The guard don't want to trade A preacher comes up here and makes a few remarks my rheumatism bothers me some yet. Playing for pins most of the day

div3.head: Wednesday 3
div3.p: Nothing new going on only we have roll call earlyer than usual. I get a letter from Mother Hamblin Jennie has gone to Saginau Mich Thos has been home and gone back

div3.head: Thursday, February 4, 1864.
div3.p: I am so lame this morning that I can hardly move Cold - and clear - a fight here while giving out the rations we get a vegetable soup in place of rice also beef & beans it is reported that a flag of truce is up.

div3.head: Friday 5
div3.p: This morning we dont get much stuff 16 loavs of bread - and two sheets of rough - and ready it all sells before night a lot of men sent here from hospital and Castle Thundr Some of them think there will be an Exchange soon.

div3.head: Saturday, February 6, 1864.
div3.p: This morning up rather early - getting some bread and rough and ready. I write to Mother Hamblin and Bessie I give my rations of beans to Burns he then does my Washing This evening I stirp and wash and change my cloths the water cold.

div3.head: Sunday 7
div3.p: Sunday has again rooled around. Burns does my wash-ing I write to Mother Hamblin The city is all excitement the Yankees are coming up the peninsula We all hope so

div3.head: Monday, February 8, 1864.
div3.p: This morning we get $5 worth of bread and a sheet of rough and ready He (Clark) gets some tobacco a flag of truce up again

div3.head: Tuesday 9
div3.p: Get up this morning with a head ache feel sick all day take a dose of salts The boys put me in Sergt of the Mess We have the Police work to do a detail is made to go out side and sweep up the streets.

div3.head: Wednesday, February 10, 1864.
div3.p: Get up this morning feeling about the same but feel better after stirring around No news of any importance only the men are taken from the first floor and sent to Bell Island. The weather fine

div3.head: Thursday 11
div3.p: We get up this morning at 5 A.M. Robberts and I make mush while Clark gets the bread. We have a very good breakfast I get a can of Condensed milk for two loaves of bread.

div3.head: Friday, February 12, 1864.
div3.p: I get a paper this morning no particular news it speaks about the Officers getting away from the Libby over one hundred make their escape by digging a tunnel Weather clear and cold.

div3.head: Saturday 13
div3.p: I hear this morning that 8 of the Officers have been retaken at night 12 more are sent in the tunnel is said to be a verry nice affair and must took some time to complete it.

div3.head: Sunday, February 14, 1864.
div3.p: Clark gets some bread & coffe and half a sheet of rough of rough and ready This morning papers say that six more of the Yankee officers have been recaptured A few words in it of an exchange of prisoners

div3.head: Monday 15
div3.p: I change my cloths cloths morning one of the boys does my washing as the cold water gives me the rheumatism Burns and I lay abead all day to keep warm, Snowing this evening the buildings are white, no trade whatever

div3.head: Tuesday, February 16, 1864.
div3.p: We all get up early this morning Clark goes to get bread Roberts and I make the mush for our Breakf-ast. 70 men are taken from this floor and placed on the first We hear that we are all going to be sent to Georgia soon Weather clear & cold

div3.head: Wednesday 17
div3.p: This morning I get up early and make coffe and get the breakfast before day light We are all taken from this floor and sent on the one next to this the other side of the buil-ding and we shall start tomorrow for Ga

div3.head: Thursday, February 18, 1864.
div3.p: We leave the building at three a.m. and take the cars We change at Petersburg in box cars We reach Gascon N.C. at dark and change cars again start for Raleigh Weather is very cold we nearly freeze in the cars

div3.head: Friday 19
div3.p: We slept very well last night the cars go very slow hardly make 10 miles an hour We get to Raleigh at 3 P.M. and then go in camp about 4 miles from the city make fires and cook our coffe Weather still cold people say the coldest of the winter

div3.head: Saturday, February 20, 1864.
div3.p: We get up early cook our coffe eat our breakfast and get ready for another start. Weather not as cold as yestardy sit around our fires untill 3 am When we draw our rations & get aboard the cars one of our men dies last night.

div3.head: Sunday 21
div3.p: Last night about midnight we run off the track no one hurt the Engine upset three cars run off. The car I am in is off a bar of iron jams through the car above my feet We are at a place called Thomas ville N.C. A train of furlough soldiers pass us from Lees army We trade with the Citizens for grub

div3.head: Monday, February 22, 1864.
div3.p: Still at Thomasville the Officers say we will get away at eleven oclock I give a testament to a little girl she gives me some thing to eat. Again under way see a few Yankee prisoners at Salsburry We arrive at Charlott at six oclock P.M. and go into camp

We start this morning at 7 P.M.{3} we cross the Catawby river River in South Carolina We reach Chester change cars this morning we buy some eatibles of the nigers People are making garden Weather warm.

div3.head: Wednesday, February 24, 1863.
div3.p: Last night we did not run much a poor nights sleep We pass through Columbia in the night change cars three miles from there we draw 4 hard tack each We pass through Branch ville at 5 oclock We cross the Savannah river at Augusta Ga.

div3.head: Tuesday 25
div3.p: We leave Augusta at 7 A.M. get rations here of crackers and meat, the Country low and Swampy. We arrive at Macon at Sun Sun set, the Guard is chan ged We lay down to sleep but it is very warm Citizens guard us.

div3.head: Friday, February 26, 1864.
div3.p: We arrive at our place of Destonation last night at 11 P.M. go to sleep on the ground No barracks are up for us but we are surrounded by a Stockaad 12 ft high we are put in squads of 100 drew rations and do our cooking I am in the 5th hundred

div3.head: Saturday 27
div3.p: This place is called Camp Sumpter Ga. To day we build us a brush house to keep us from the weather Robberts makes a corn bred for supper Reid goes to the Hospital as Steward The boys are making brier wood pipes

div3.head: Sunday, February 28, 1864.
div3.p: Last night another lot of Prisoners came in some old Prisoners from my Regt 2 from my Company Fuller & Sarsney Clark has poisend himself in the swamp by being in the swamp Still warm for the season

div3.head: Monday 29
Sunday, May 8, 1864.
div3.p: Dr White sends in word that I must stay inside of the Stockade if I am Commissary and attend to bringing in the medicine the reason for this is Ed and Reid had a row about the Quinine. A verry pleas-ant day

div3.head: Monday 9
div3.p: Dr White and some other Officers inspect the Hospital. Ed brings in plenty of Hospital supp-lies to day. No particular news of the battle before Richmond. Think it is nearly a draw-game

div3.head: Tuesday, May 10, 1864.
div3.p: Rather Cloudy and looks like rain but is hot & sultry Dr White sends in two turkeys to make broth of for the sick We have now over 700 sick in North & South Hospital - a light diet for the number

div3.head: Wednesday 11
div3.p: I go to the Dispensary with the Dr to get some black pepper The bakery has now got in opperation and we get plenty of bread for all hands. it has rained nearly all day. no more news in regard to the battle before Richmond

div3.head: Thursday, May 12, 1864.
div3.p: The weather more cool. Ed is sick - does not go-out side to day Frank Halstead comes over to see the boys. Receive a letter from Mother Hamblin it was wrote the 22nd of April only 20 days on the way

We make out a morning report of - all in Hospital and send to Head Quarters I get a verry large ration of fresh beef the most I have had at any one time Dilly sends me in some paper and Envellopes. The old Capt finds a tunnel under the Stockad below the Hospital

div3.head: Saturday, May 14, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing new in the reports today. the Garrison is Reviewed by Gen Cobb. A large number of Ladies - are present A sham battle is fought I wash and change my clothing. We think we shall be Exch-anged when the Spring Campaign is over

div3.head: Sunday 15
div3.p: The Drs sat that the Hospital is going to be moved out side of the Stockade soon The Senty one of the sentinels shoot the old one leged man for getting - across the dead line. it is still warm as usual. no particular news to day

div3.head: Monday, May 16, 1864.
div3.p: Quartermaster don't send me in full rations of meat to day it is most plaguey warm To day my tearm of enlistment expires having served the US Government in the Volunteer Services three years

div3.head: Tuesday 17
div3.p: We hear to day that we shall undoubtedly move out side this week. We hear that Dalton is now in our hands No news from Virginia that we can rely on the Rebels say that Grant has been drove back but we cant see the point

div3.head: Wednesday, May 18, 1864.
div3.p: Dr Alexander tells Ed that the Exchange is going on, hope it is so and that we may be started towards our lines in a few days I write a letter to Mother Hamblin this afternoon. Frank Beverstock comes over to see Ed and myself

div3.head: Thursday 19
div3.p: I go over to see Frank Garland to have him do some tattooing for me. We have a game of cards this even ing to pass away the time Weather still hot. no news from the fronts

div3.head: Friday, May 20, 1864.
div3.p: We have rool call at 7 AM earlier than usual The Dr tells me that we shall be moved soon but they have told it so many times it has got to be an old story weather Host & dry

div3.head: Saturday 21
div3.p: I get up early and have Frank prick the Godess of Liberty on my arm. at ten Oclock we go out side with the Hospital it is in a verry pleas-ant grove but it is tedious moving the sick. I have put a blister on my arm to take out the ink that was pricked in the morning.

div3.head: Sunday, May 22, 1864.
div3.p: The north Hospital is moved out to day it is hot as fury I have to carey my arm in a sling it is so sore Dr White - comes in and gives me full charge of the Commassary Department No news to day from the front.

div3.head: Monday 23
div3.p: We have 172 new patients admitted to hospital it is verry hot and we have but few nurses they have to work verry hard. Another new lot of fedral prisoners come in the stockade some of them from the 5th Army Corps

div3.head: Tuesday, May 24, 1864.
div3.p: Not as warm as yestardy - a cool breeze blowing, a few new admission to Hospital. More Fedral Prisoners come in. news from our Armies is cheering Grant is driving Lee back towards Richmond

div3.head: Wednesday 25
div3.p: My arm not much better it looks verry bad We have more patients admitted to Hospital so that we now have some over 800 patients - and 100 attend-ants - and I have plenty of work to do. It is warm and sultry

div3.head: Thursday, May 26, 1864
div3.p: We have a lot more sick admitted from the stockades Robinson lets three of us go out to the creek and have a swim, still hot as ever The policeman and myself fix up my tent so that I can keep my stores from being stole.

div3.head: Friday 27
div3.p: My arm is getting worse inflammation has got in it and it is verry sore The Garreson are in line of battle nearly all day as they expect that the boys will make a break

div3.head: Saturday, May 28, 1864.
div3.p: Every thing about as usual no news of any exchange we hear that our Army under Gen Sherman is within 15 miles of Atlanta and Gen Jo Johnston is more than skedadling to keep him from taking the place.. 60 more patients admitted

div3.head: Sunday 29
div3.p: Nothing new going on 1100 more prisoners came in to-day, part of them lately captured in the battles before Richmond they bring - cheering news say Grant is driving Lee back every day

div3.head: Monday, May 30, 1864.
div3.p: Charley Tabor goes out side - and Dr White gives him - a pass to pass out & in when he pleases. A lot more prisoners come in to day from the Army of the Potomac All the news we get from there is cheering for us Grant has captured 87 pieces of cannon

div3.head: Tuesday 31
div3.p: I send a note in to Frenchy to find out how many of my Regt have lately come inside of the Stockade. We hear nothing from the seat of war to day of any importance.

div3.head: Wednesday, June 1, 1864.
div3.p: Rumors again around Camp that we are to be exch-anged soon or paroled and is to take place the 10th or 15th of the month We have a fine shower of rain it is verry hot for an hour or two.

div3.head: Thursday 2
div3.p: This afternoon it clouds up and rains very hard I set and play cards with Bishop, Snider and Ed Burns no reports - going round to day still hot

div3.head: Friday, June 3, 1864.
div3.p: It is verry hot and dry the sand sokes up all the rain it rains again to- day verry hard We hear again that we shall be exchanged soon I hope it may be so

div3.head: Saturday 4
div3.p: We have to make only one kettle of gruel this morning it has rained nearly all-day Dr White comes in and inspects the Camp I get only half rations of bread to day when I got full rations part of it spoils

div3.head: Sunday, June 5, 1864.
div3.p: I change my Cloths wash up - and get my work - done up in good season. News is scarse again I buy 2.50 in gold to day at a preamium of 75 cts. I am offered at the rate of three for one for it

div3.head: Monday 6
div3.p: It is warm and muggy it clouds up and rains. the Dr says Grant is within 6 miles of Richmond and he seems to think that Richmond is going up.

div3.head: Tuesday, June 7, 1864.
div3.p: I go out side to day and - get the Syrup; and try to - get more skillets & bucketts 600 more Union Prisoners come in to day from Va They bring no particular news - how the fight is going but think Grant will be successful

div3.head: Wednesday 8
div3.p: I have a plenty of bread come in again, to day but verry little rice - it is reported that Atlanta is in our hands The news from Rich mond is cheering Gen Lee is now within his Fortifica tions in front of the City

div3.head: Thursday, June 9, 1864.
div3.p: I get a new pair of pants pay one dollar for - getting them made - and one Dollar for the bags. it rains - again to day. The papers say the Commi-sssoners - are together again trying to fix up an exchange hope they will - aggree and we poor Devels have a chance to see home again

div3.head: Friday 10
div3.p: Very warm - again. it is reported that Richmond is ours but the report is contradicted - the papers say Grant had fought with them at Gains Mill - and that is within 7 miles of the City

div3.head: Saturday, June 11, 1864.
div3.p: Every thing about as usual re news from the front.. I get Rations of fresh beef also a lot of greens for the skirvy cases but there is not a taste for one half of the patients

div3.head: Sunday 12
div3.p: I have some work to do this morning in cleaning up my tent. I write a short letter to Mother Hamblin this evening; it clouds up and rains like the old scratch for an hour or more.

div3.head: Monday, June 13, 1864.
div3.p: This morning I get no bread for the sick nothing but pork isshued I have to ishue rations of rice to the attend-ants to supply the place of bread I write a letter to my Sister Jennie at Saginau Michigan I now have three to mail to night it is a rainy day I buy a watch for $30

div3.head: Tuesday 14
div3.p: It has been a wet cold nasty day rains about half of the time Frank is rather better I buy a small chicken for him pay 75 cts for it. Ed heard to day that President Lincoln has ishued an order that all prisoners were to be exchanged or paroled immediately

div3.head: Wednesday, June 15, 1864
div3.p: I go out side to day to get molasses. We get two pails full of it. 1100 more Federal Prisoners came in Captured in Va I see three from my Regiment that have reenlisted Dr White gives me a pass to pass out and in hospital A few Officers exchanged from Macon

div3.head: Thursday 16
div3.p: This morning I get up I see it is a gain cloudy it has tried to rain most of the day but has not made it out. Frank is rather weaker - 1100 more Federal Prisoners come in Some of them captured at Petersburg Va News Encourageing for us

div3.head: Friday, June 17, 1864.
div3.p: Still rains continually has rained every day this month so far. We get a fine lot of greens cooked to day. I sell a watch to Charles Tabor for $55.00 Major Bogle comes in to the Hospital as a patient. We hear no news of any kind from the Army

div3.head: Saturday 18
div3.p: This has been a verry wet nas ty day - cold and chilly. the papers say that the wheat is growing in some places Torpedo Jack are sentenced to be hung. Gen Winder paroled them and sends them to the penetentary - during the war no news from the fronts Frank a little better

div3.head: Sunday, June 19, 1864
div3.p: I wash up and change my cloths and go out to the dispinsary after molasses - and vinegar but get none I came back to my tent and write a letter to Maria Hayden Frank thinks he is not as well to day This is a clear sunshiny day no rain

div3.head: Monday 20
div3.p: We think we are going to have a verry fine day as it is clear as crystal but about 4 O.Clock P M it clouds up and rains for a coupple of hours very heard . my rations when they come in are verry wet I get a ration of fresh beef the cooks cook out at night

div3.head: Tuesday, June 21, 1864.
div3.p: Frank not quite so well to-day has been eating stewed plums I get molasses again to day. It has been verry pleasant and rained but little. Some more news of an Exchange say it is to take place some time next month I put away $30.00 for future use.

div3.head: Wednesday 22
div3.p: When I get up this mor-ning I feel rather down the mouth - don't do any work until evening when the flour comes in then I isshue out 800 rations it is reported that our sco-uts were within 7 miles of here a day ago. Corpl Wm O Dillingham Died June 20th Co I Mich Infty No of grave 2278

div3.head: Thursday, June 23, 1864.
div3.p: This has been a verry warm day and no rain hope we shall have no more for a week There is some talk that we shall be Exchanged undoubtedly next month. We hear to-day that we are going to be searched Burns & I put away some over $200. Frank better

div3.head: Friday 24
div3.p: This has been a verry warm day the warmest of any we have yet had I get a lot of greens and a large ration of fresh beef We hear no particular news of any Exchange any more than we shall likely be exchanged some time next month

div3.head: Saturday, June 25, 1864.
div3.p: We get another quantity of Vegetables. the Cooks are verry busy cooking greens and fresh beef. Frank is gaining finely We have some good news from Gen Grant he is within 3 miles of Petersburgh has captured 6 Batteries from Lee. Buley for us

div3.head: Sunday 26
div3.p: This has been a verry warm day. We get more fresh beef and Vegt [-] makes a fine potatoes stew and Blackberry Duff Two years ago to day the 7 days battles - commenced on the Peninsula Va commen-cing at Mechanicsville.

div3.head: Monday, June 27, 1864.
div3.p: This has been a verry warm day We really melt with heat. Gaines goes out with us to help bring in the vinegar and molasses Fresh beef again to-day We hear that Sherman and Johnson are again fighting at Marrietta Ga 2 Years to day the 7 days battles commenced

div3.head: Tuesday 28
div3.p: Rather more air stiring than usual. I go up to Head Quarters twice to day. Get more molasses than usual. We hear that cars are being fixed up to transport the sick in when the Exch-ange takes place hope it will be soon

div3.head: Wednesday, June 29, 1864.
div3.p: This has been a verry warm day. As good luck will have it I get no fresh beef, but about 35 bags of vegetables I ishue no flour to the pat-ients [Line inserted that is not discernable.] We hear that Gen Winder has received ord ers that there will be no Exchanges during the war

div3.head: Thursday 30
div3.p: Great Excitement in Camp the raiders have been taken out of the stock- ade and are having a Jury trial, by our own men. Public opinion cries loud -ly to hang them 2 men have been found in one of there teants dead still hot and Sultry.

div3.head: Friday, July 1, 1864.
div3.p: This has been a verry hot day. I don't go after my Vinegar and molasses untill 7 Oclock. The news from Northern Ga and Virginia about as us- ual. 2 years ago today the Battle of Malvern Hill Col Woodburry of the 7th Mich Killed.

div3.head: Saturday 2
div3.p: Still warm and sultry I get a quantity of bags again any ammount of squashes given out the boys in the new stock-ad 1 year ago Col Jeffes of the 7 Mich Killed at Gettysburg Pa News from Va cheering from Grants army. Petersburg is ours

div3.head: Sunday, July 3, 1864.
div3.p: This has been another hot day. I go up to Hd Qtrs early and get my syrrup Vinegar & salt. This after noon a party of us go over to the creek and have a fine bath. I buy one Doz of eggs pay $2 for them We hear no news of any importance

div3.head: Monday 4
div3.p: I finish reading the Bible through this morning. I then go and get my mol-asses it rains about two hours - and has been rather a dry Independance to us prisoners. Jim cooks a fine Blackburry Duff for supper. No Whiskey at Hd Quarters for patients

div3.head: Tuesday, July 5, 1864.
div3.p: This has been another warm day. nearly hot enough to suffocate a person I go out early to get molasses & vinegar Henan goes with me. Newton owns up that Grant has possission of Petersburg and that we hold Danville.

div3.head: Wednesday 6
div3.p: Last night Ed and I got rather more liquor down than we can hold - consequently we heave up Jonah - and have both been sick all day neither of us has done any work. The Cooks boil three kettles of Simlins for sick. Weather still hot.

div3.head: Thursday, July 7, 1864.
div3.p: This has been another verry warm day We hear it reported that Johnson has been whipped from Marrietta and is now within nine miles of Atlanta We also hear that Kilpatrick is making a raid on Macon and he is expected here. The Women have been ordered away from here.

div3.head: Friday 8
div3.p: I go up to Hhd Qters early. help Frank Hunt put up a tent. I have to give a receipt for what molasses & vinegar I draw for Hospital use. Cars all runing hourly by here. The address of Miss O.M. Smith is Nottoway T. Kalamazoo Mich. Still Hot.

div3.head: Saturday, July 9, 1864.
div3.p: This morning I go up to Hhd Qtrs rather early and get the molasses & vinegar. About 800 prisoners just came in from the Army of the Potomac - captured at Petersburg Mrs Hunt is blessed with a young son. A fine shower this evening.

div3.head: Sunday 10
div3.p: This is the hottest day we have had. I have to cut rations of meat for the attendants. Another lot of Federal Prisoners - are brought in We hear that Sherman has taken Atlanta Tim gives us a blackburry Duff for dinner. A shower coming up.

div3.head: Monday, July 11, 1864.
div3.p: This morning at 8 AM Frank captures a thief in our tent stealing meat we keep him tied untill after day light when I let him go. Dr White sends in another Kettle for cooking purposses The six Deserters Raiders are hung to day at 5 oclock Haines & I go out and see them

div3.head: Tuesday 12
div3.p: This morning I take two of the boys and go out and get some crotches and fix my tent I now have it higher and much more convenient. Old Charley tells me that the Pirate 21 is distroyed and that Atlanta is now in yankee hands Still hot. No news from Rich-mond

div3.head: Wednesday, July 13, 1864.
div3.p: I get a chance to see todays paper. it states that Sherm-an has crossed the Chattahoechi - also that Gen Early is now in Maryland and that Gen Grant has returned to the north bank of the James River. This has been the warmest day we have had Theremometer ranging 105

div3.head: Thursday 14
div3.p: This morning a general reno-vation of camp takes place and streets are lade out and it is now much more pleas-ant. I have to move my tent. keeps Ed and I busy for an hour or two. This morning I get a wagon load of bread but is now all given out. The alarm guns all fire

div3.head: Tuesday, July 19, 1864.
div3.p: To day I go up to head Qtrs get 2 bucketts of Molasses and I get 7 sacks flour. We hear that our Cavelry is making a raid this way. I hear that six delegates are to start tomor-row for our lines to see if an exchange cant be mad so as to benefit us prisoners. We have a cotellian this evening still hot

div3.head: Wednesday 20
div3.p: This morning the rebs set a party of Darkies atwork throwing up breast- works - Newton tells me that Our forces are expe-cted here to night or to morrow. They have burnt Columbia 55 miles from here The weather still very hot No news from Grant

div3.head: Thursday, July 21, 1864.
div3.p: When I go up to Hhd. Qtrs after molasses I see that the Rebs have about 300 Niggers throwing up breas-works we heard that Fighting is going on near Altanta hope we may be successful Reported that Johnson is supper -sceeded by Gen Hood

div3.head: Friday 22
div3.p: To day the same old thing as usual no news from the front. We hear that 90 of our cavelry that made the raid to Columbus have been captured. The weather still hot. Reports in the papers say that Gen Grant is dead but we don't believe it

div3.head: Saturday, July 23, 1864.
div3.p: To-day has been rather cool the Rebs are now throwing up rifle pits over the run. We also hear that the rebels commenced evacuating Atlanta last night, but the papers say that Sherman is whipped and 4 Generals killed I go to Dr Barrows tent & we have some fine music

div3.head: Sunday 24
div3.p: I go up to Hhd Quarters about noon and get my molasses. Such a time as I have in giving it out the boys are so thick it is almost impossible to move I cut a whip to lick a few of them it has been rather windy. Report says that Sherman has been Defeated

div3.head: Monday, July 25, 1864.
div3.p: Last night about midnight the guard shoots one of the patients through the leg Dr White amputates it to day. We have a Devel of an uproar about the flour no Attendants now - are allowed - any We get some greens and a few early green corn Charly gives me $10.

div3.head: Tuesday 26
div3.p: Nothing new to day we hear no news from the Armies. The Rebs have 8 more pieces of artilery here now making 16 in all They are at work on the Fortifications but no guns in position. We have new potatoes & corn for tea

div3.head: Wednesday, July 27, 1864.
div3.p: This morning I am feeling rather down - and don't do much work Tom Lyles goes up to Hhd Quarters in my place and gets the molasses. A lot of wounded prisoners come in to day Captured near Atlanta. They say that we are whipping Hood every day Still hot

div3.head: Thursday 28
div3.p: I am feeling better again to day I go out and get the molasses. The rebs have their fort nearly finished, and 8 guns in position. The Captain fires a shell over the Stockade to scare the men a lot more are put in taken at Atlanta

div3.head: Friday, July 29, 1864.
div3.p: This morning - another Detail comes out of the Stockade. We have now about 1700 patients and about 300 of them are wounded half of them wounded near Atlanta We are rather getting the best of them there.

div3.head: Saturday 30
div3.p: This has been another verry warm day I go up to Hhd Qatrs about noon and get my molasses. Ed and I buy a large watermellon and a verry nice one Report says the Yankees are shelling Atlanta - every body scared here Guns are got into position [-]

div3.head: Sunday, July 31, 1864.
div3.p: This morning I hurry up the ward masters and have them draw their flour & beans and at 10 oclock I am done my work and cloths changed We hear that our forces all at Macon and have burnt the Pistol Factory it is thought they will be here tomorrow

div3.head: Monday, August 1
div3.p: The excitement is now - at ebb but the trees have all been cut to make room for artillery practice 12 guns are now mounted in the fort Ed is now Steward of a ward. I write to Mother Hamblin and Sister Jennie more rumors of an Exchange.

div3.head: Tuesday, August 2, 1864.
div3.p: Warm as usual - but no news of importance but it is rumored that General Stoneman and staff have been Captured we cant half believe it We get a very heavy shower this after-noon A few more sick come in again we expect 500 to be admitted tomorrow

div3.head: Wednesday 3
div3.p: This morning I send in the Stockade to get Joe Stevens out for a nurse. 600 sick are admitted to Hospital - we have hardly room - enough to accommodate a ¼ of them. It is rumored that the Hospital is going to be removed.

div3.head: Thursday, August 4, 1864.
div3.p: It is a hard looking sight this morning to see so many sick men laying on the ground The attendents have to give up their tents for patients. 25 Detailed men come out of Stock-ade for nurses Mighty hot - day no news

div3.head: Friday 5
div3.p: To day there is more rumors that the exchange is to be resumed and that 6000 of the trans Misaspi prisoners have been excha-nged under the new cartel 300 more patients have been admitted to day we have no place to put them Still hot and dry

div3.head: Saturday, August 6, 1864.
div3.p: This morning Frank is detailed for Assint. Steward in 3rd Division under Mason The Rebs have commenced throwing up breast works south of Hospital they now have 7 Forts two of them finished We get no molasses to day I send in Stockade for

div3.head: Sunday 7
div3.p: This morning big excite-ment in camp we hear that six men are agoing to start tomorrow with Dispatches to our Governm-ent to try and affect an exhange I write a letter to Mason to send with them To days paper says the exchange is agreed upon

div3.head: Monday, August 8, 1864.
div3.p: Last night I am taken with the colic - about 11 P.M. Ed gets up and goes and gets me some medicine I feel bad and lay abead all day do no work. Rains like fury for a few moments Joe Stevens comes out of the Stockade on Detail he tells me lots of news

div3.head: Tuesday 9
div3.p: Today it rains very hard the Stockade falls over in 4 different places. The garison is all turned out and the fort is filled with men. Now days I have more corn bread than I know what to do with Dr Mc Veigh says 1500 men are to be sent to Beaufort S.C.

div3.head: Wednesday, August 10
div3.p: To day we hear no particular news of the Exchange but it is thought we shall get away from here next month To day it rains verry hard for two hours the Senter of the Stockade falls over in front & Rear.

div3.head: Thursday 11
div3.p: Last night rains most of the time I go up to Hhd Qtrs for molasses but get none. Some one goes into my knapsack and steals a pint flask of whiskey that I have laid away for some future use rains again to day every thing [-] In [--]

div3.head: Friday, August 12, 1864.
div3.p: To day I have to isshue flour in the afternoon. I give out 1600 rations without getting up from my seat - No particular news from the armies but Newton tells me that Mobiel is clostly invested by the Yankee forces Still warm

div3.head: Saturday 13
div3.p: This morning I don't get as much bread by six hundred pounds but get more rice Ed goes to bead early but I sit up half of the night it is so hot Sergt Paul of the regiment gets on a bum No news from the Army

div3.head: Sunday, August 14, 1864.
div3.p: To day has been a dull lonesom day not much to day to do until the flour comes in then I ishue 1904 rations some few admissions are made from the Stockade I go up to Hhd Qtrs and get salt then down to the creek and have a swim

div3.head: Monday 15
div3.p: No special news to day some excitement in regard to Citizens but I don't think it will amount to much. Not as warm as usual I have been thinking of when I am going to get home I wish to see Father & Mother also Jennie and Maria. I hope they are well

div3.head: Tuesday, August 16, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing new going on to day. We hear no news from Richmond think there is no communication. The Drs are telling the sick that a lot of them are going to be sent to Macon in a few days as the accommodations are better there Weather still hot. A shower this eve.

div3.head: Wednesday 17
div3.p: We hear to day that the Exchange is going on and notices of it are stuck up in the Stockade and all are in good spirits I think it is all a hoax Rumor says that Capt [-] is dead died of Typhoid Fever. Still hot as ever.

div3.head: Thursday, August 18, 1864.
div3.p: I go out side and have a fine bath water over 7 feet deep Molley came near drowning get in to water over his head I help him out. three more prisoners come in to day they think we all are to be Exchanged soon. No news from the Army.

div3.head: Friday 19
div3.p: To day they are moving Hhd Qtrs the Drug room is now moved in the camp of the 55th Georgia We have a fine shower this even-ing. No new reports to day about the Exchange I feel verry confidant that we shall be exchanged next month. Still hot

div3.head: Saturday, August 20, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing new to day there-fore I have not much to do or to write about I go up to Hhd Qtrs but find it is moved. Not as hot to day as usual we have a shower this afternoon I get a yestardays paper find that the Exchange has been made between Gens Jones and Gen Lee

div3.head: Sunday 21
div3.p: I get my cloths changed early and Ed and I think of going out and getting some watermelons but it commences raining and we cant go Rations come in verry late I [-] out every bit of Flour 600 pounds We now cook our beef at night for conveniance sake

div3.head: Monday, August 22, 1864.
div3.p: To day is the same old thing over every day brings the same rotine of business No particular news of the Exchange. The papers are blowing because the Government is Exchanging the Officers & leaving the Privates to languish in this miserable hole. Still hot as ever

div3.head: Tuesday 23
div3.p: This forenoon Tabor and I go out prospecting but mostly in search of Grapes but don't succeed in finding any Flour in early I am all done ishueing at noon I am not bothered to death with orders from the Drs to patients Succotash for Dinner. Still hot and sultry

div3.head: Wednesday, August 24, 1864.
Thursday 25
div3.p: Ed and I go over to see Ed and Frenchy we come back and stop in the woods and have a swim - a stream called the Sweet water. I get on a drunk this evening - get sick and have a time of Vomiting then don't feel so well.

div3.head: Friday, August 26, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing special this morning and no news from the front. But this afternoon there is great Excitement News in the papers say that the (2) Two Governments have aggreed uppon an immediate exchange Most every one is hopeful I think it is all a Gammon

div3.head: Saturday 27
div3.p: This morning a fine lot of Delicacies are sent to the Sick by the Ladies of Americus. Lieut Davis says he is expecting orders every day to send Prisoners from here to be Exchanged. A small amount of clothing is ishued this morning I get a Blouse Sent from Richmond Still hot

div3.head: Sunday, August 28, 1864.
div3.p: My work is done up this morning at 9 am Flour is in before the Corn- bread. I go up to Dr White about getting more flour as I am 100 lbs short Charley gets on a tight is sick a part of the day More news in the papers about an Exchange

div3.head: Monday 29
div3.p: This has been a very warm day. There has been a lot of new tents put up for the use of the Sick. Dr White gives me one for a sleeping tent as my old one is not large enough for what I have to keep in it. Ed and I go out and have a fine swim No particular news of the Exchange

div3.head: Tuesday, August 30, 1864.
div3.p: We hear it rumored this morning that the R.R. Co have been ordered by the Government Authorities that they must do all of their ship-ing between now and the 10th of Sept as they will be taken for to trans-port prisoners from here but I cant see the Transfers

div3.head: Wednesday 31
div3.p: No news of importance to be relied upon I see the paper a few words about the exch-ange it says that every thing is satisfactorily arranged and that it will take place in a few days. I go over to the Burial yard

div3.head: Thursday, September 1, 1864.
div3.p: To day the Passes given by Dr White play out Capt Wirz now has to give all Tomorrow they say we have got to give up the old ones and if we need another it will be given us. No Flour as yet but a plenty of Corn bread 208 Cards this morning none this Evening

div3.head: Friday 2
div3.p: No particular news this morning about the old Rosencrans advancing on Macon We hear that Gen Sherman is falling back from Atlanta the Rebs think he cant ret-reat far as Forrest is in his rear A few more words concerning the Exchange

div3.head: Saturday, September 3, 1864.
div3.p: This morning we here no reports from the front The paper this afternoon say that Hood cannot hold Atlanta. Sherman has made a flank move and drawn them out then he swings his left in and captures 15000 prisoners so says reports in paper

div3.head: Sunday 4
div3.p: This has been a very ple-asant day. I have been out in the woods sitting in the shade thinking of loved ones at home & wondering if they all were well. Dance gives me 15 gallons of Molasses to ishue I give some to all the Attendants A few more words of Exchange in to day

div3.head: Monday, September 5, 1864.
div3.p: News to day come in the report that Atlanta has fallen{6}Sherman captured the City and 18000 Priso-ners Some of them don't like to own it and say that it is just a flying report We are short of rations of meat 200 pounds Flour again 600 lbs the best ever I have drawn

div3.head: Tuesday 6
div3.p: This morning I hear that Sherman captured 28000 prisoners. Papers say 5000 Charley and I go out to get syrup and a barrel to make beer in 2 years ago to night I got Home in Chittenary Report says that a lot of Prisoners are to leave here [---] sent for Exchange{7}

div3.head: Wednesday, September 7, 1864.
div3.p: This morning at 9 A.M. 800 prisoners leave here said to be going to Charles-ton & Savannah about three hundred go from the Hospital Taber goes also Tim Ed and I pack up to go but conclude to wait until tomorrow I am rather fea-rful that is a hoax

div3.head: Thursday 8
div3.p: We hear this morning that 3000 prisoners have now left the Stockade I try and go the Dr wants me to wait until the hospital is sent. Exciteme- nt runs high all want to go. This evening we hear that it is only a removal of prisoners from this post.

div3.head: Friday, September 9, 1864.
div3.p: Burns goes to see Leenox about the exchange he says he knows it to be so says he is going when the Hospit-al is sent. I want to go to night I hear that the trans-ports are at Savannah waiting for prisoners (Federal) as they have brought down 20000 Rebels. We hear that a part of the sick will go Monday

div3.head: Saturday 10
div3.p: No special news to day - only 2 trains go away to day. We hear that no exch-ange has been affected and the removal is made to keep the prisoners from falling in our mens hands the Rebs are afraid Sherman may send a raiding party here to relieve us

div3.head: Sunday, September 11, 1864.
div3.p: {8}This has been a long lones-ome day I get my work done early and go out side A large lot taken from the Stockade to day Two years ago to night Mother and Marcia made a party for me as I was at home still [-]

div3.head: Monday 12
div3.p: No news to day of any kind The prisoners are still being removed from the Stockade We hear to day that there is no exchange we are being removed from here to keep us from fa'lly into Shermans hands if he should make a raid down here. Still warm

div3.head: Tuesday, September 13, 1864.
div3.p: I go over to Hhd Qtrs and get 20 gallons molasses for hospital use all hands get some it is said there is only 5000 men now left in the Stockade I hear that they are sent to Savannah and are laying there under Guard within 1 ½miles of the city sell my pipe for $39

div3.head: Wednesday 14
div3.p: This morning I see a few of the men that were wounded by the cars running of the track one man had his foot amp-utated 14 were killed outright The fireman died here this morning was a negro was scalded so that his skin hung in ribbons No more news of the exchange.

div3.head: Thursday, September 15, 1864.
div3.p: No particular news from the Army Sherman & Hood have aggreed uppon a ten day armistice The Drs now say that the prisoners sent away from here have been sent to Millen Ga to another prison Charley Tabers Father came here last night to see him has gone to Savannah to day

div3.head: Friday 16
div3.p: We get up a petition to send Gen [-] to see if we cant get a committee sent to Gen Sherman to affect an exchange for this Hospital I lend Ezra C. Jones 2.50. cts his Pa Address is Ezra Jones. Canoga Seneca Co. N. York still hot and dry Sherman & Hood trying to exchange 2000 men

div3.head: Saturday, September 17, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing new going on here this evening morning Dr Kerr comes in to take out one of the men to put him in the Stocks for stealing meat. This after noon great excitement is created news comes that 2000 prisoners are to be exchanged between Hood and Sherman I put my name down to go but now think it is a hoax

div3.head: Sunday 18
div3.p: Last night was a rainy one has been cloudy all day 700 men go from the Stockade we go tomorrow it is said to shermans lines for Special Exchange. This is my birth day 25 years of age. Wish I was home with Mother Hamblin and Maria think I would be contented.

div3.head: Monday, September 19, 1864.
div3.p: Ed and I get our washing done up it is said we shall leave between six and 12 this evening but we don't go 1100 are taken from the Stockade if we go to our lines we must go between now and Thurs-day morning as then the armistice expires

div3.head: Tuesday 20
div3.p: More news this morning it is rumored that the Hospital has orders to be ready to move at a moments notice 1200 more are expected to leave to night. We think we shall stand a chance of going this time no news lately from Richmond

div3.head: Wednesday, September 21, 1864.
div3.p: This has been a wet day and looks some like fall of the year in the northern states We hear it reported that this 200 men are held in reserve and will be sent Some think we shall go to night I have about give up our going but still have hopes of it No news from the front

div3.head: Thursday 22
div3.p: We hear nothing to day that we can place any reliance uppon The Sergt of the gate says that two trains are waiting at the Depot for prisoners that 200 are going to Sherman lines and 200 Sailors are going to Charleston

div3.head: Friday, September 23, 1864.
div3.p: No news to day of any imp-ortance we hear that one regiment of Ga troops turned back after leaving Jones-bourough but took the oath of alleigance rather than come back in the Confederacy it tries very hard to rain the most of the day Skirmishing again at the Front

div3.head: Saturday 24
div3.p: We have had two verry fine showers to day Joe has been telling some of his yarns I have been writing to Jennie and Mother Hamblin we hear that a regiment of Georgians took the oath of allegiance to our Government rather than be exchanged and fight again

div3.head: Sunday, September 25, 1864.
div3.p: This has been rather a long day this forenoon I wrote to Maria Hayden then ishued out the flour to patients read a macon paper and finished reading a book entitled Dictionary of Love Ed Has been writing home this afternoon a warm day.

div3.head: Monday 26
div3.p: This morning Burns & I go over to the grave yard We hear that old Jeffy Davis is coming here to see this Camp tomorrow We also hear that he says he will release all prisoners whose times are out before he will feed them this winter.

div3.head: Tuesday, September 27, 1864.
div3.p: To day the Sailors are taken from here to be sent away for exchange but the engine is broke down and they are sent back and are now awaiting orders to move We hear nothing more about going to Shermans lines Weather moderate

div3.head: Wednesday 28
div3.p: Last night at 8 P.M. Sailors left here Glunt goes with them They carry three letters for me I get a paper to day. No news in it rega-rding the Armys They keep harping on the fall of Atlanta and wonder why old Jeff D don't take it back

div3.head: Thursday, September 29, 1864
div3.p: Last night I take two pills of blue mass and this morning a dose of oil and laudanum have felt rather down the most of the day Ed and Jhony wheel in some new sand in the tent We heard last night that Sherman hade been whipped back from Atlanta no news of it to day

div3.head: Friday 30
div3.p: This morning I am feeling fine well as usual the papers say that Butler and Old have aggreed to Exchange 5000 sick and wounded the Exchange point Fort Pulaski When it is to take place we know not No news from the Armies Ed and I go out and wash

div3.head: Saturday, Oct. 1, 1864
div3.p: A few sick admitted from the stockade we now have about 1700 patients I get nine sacks flour ishue it all out We hear no news from the armies. We finish the oven in 2nd Division and commence one in the 1st I lay a few brick Warm for the first

div3.head: Sunday 2
div3.p: I hurray and do up my morning work wash shave off my whiskers and then go over to the Depot, and see a few of the boys there Eislick is now cooking for the Detectives I hear that all Soldiers whose tearms of enlistment have not exp-ired are to be exchanged

div3.head: Monday, October 3, 1864
div3.p: We hear no news to day about the exchange We div-ide up here and I now ishue to the Division Commissary which makes it much more convenient We get a verry heavy shower lasting nearly an hour. A confederate engineer comes here for the wheelbarrow. fortifying at Millan

div3.head: Tuesday 4
div3.p: This morning the Commis-sarys of each Division ishue to their own attendants. Dr Kerr gives me a pair of platform scales to weigh out supplies I give out flour and rice by weight Burns and Len put a fly over the tent weather fair

div3.head: Wednesday, October 5, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing new to day in regard to news I get a paper of the 4th a few dispatches from Richmond but nothing from Sherman Rumor says that Gen Bureguard now has com-mand of Hoods Army.

div3.head: Thursday 6
div3.p: To day has passed about like yestardy Ed gets a paper news rather scarse [-] made Division Steward of 3rd Division. I have been reading most of the day a book called Vio-let or the Cross & Crown Weather Cool.

div3.head: Friday, October 7, 1864.
div3.p: I finish reading my book and then do my ishueing flour and rice Ed and three others of us play poker most of the afternoon, it is very warm for Oct William is sent to Stockade this morning for stea-ling patients whiskey

div3.head: Saturday 8
div3.p: Last night there was a great change in the weat-her it is cold enough to chill and a fire feels very comfortable We get a large lot of sweet po- tatoes and one bag of irish also a few dried apples No news from the front.

div3.head: Sunday, October 9, 1864.
div3.p: Last night Hogan and four other men from the out side run away it is reported that they were armed. The dogs have been out but could not strike the trail. Success to them in their undertaking Nothing from the Army

div3.head: Monday 10
div3.p: We hear no news from the Army of the west some Telegraph news from Petersburg Va Grant is again man-uvering his army. We hear it reported by Officers that Hood is in the rear of Sherman destroying the Rail Road

div3.head: Tuesday, October 11, 1864.
div3.p: This morning it is rep-orted that Forest has captured Gen Sherman as he was returning from Washington we don't believe the report. A few more prisoners are bro-ught here from Va. Last night Hogan was brought back and placed in Stock

div3.head: Wednesday 12
div3.p: Weather is again more pleasant but cool morning and evening Some new rumors in regard to the exchange of sick and wou-nded some say that Maj Mulford is on his way to Savannah with 10 000 confederate Soldiers to be exchanged for a like number of ours.

div3.head: Thursday, October 13, 1864.
div3.p: We hear this morning that Hood has tore up the rail road and destroyed Shermans Communications and captured larg trains of supplies. Also that Sherman has fallen back from Atlanta and burnt the City. Hogan released from the Stocks and in stockade.

div3.head: Friday 14
div3.p: No news to day from Gen Sherman we think that he is yet all right. Some of the boys go out and help Dr Credill put up a log house. More cool again. I write a few receipts and finish readg a book entitled Machard A Southern Yarn of the War.

div3.head: Saturday, October 15, 1864.
div3.p: The confederates say that Gen Sherman has gone to Washington they are making calculations to capture him so they say we don't see the capture We now don't get but 6 or 700 lbs beef daily I get 104 gallons molasses in place of meet , one gallon for 18 men A very pleasant day.

div3.head: Sunday 16
div3.p: This morning Burns and I wheel in some sand to fill up the tent. We treat all our friends on beer as we have a barrel full of [word lined out] made of corn meal, molasses, and water Len is getting the Syrup. No news from the front. I write a letter to Maria Hayden

div3.head: Monday, October 17, 1864.
div3.p: This has been rather of cloudy hazy day and looks very much like fall of the year. I get 73 gallons syrup to day we hear no news from the front only it is rumo-red that Gen Hood is in rather clost quarters with no chance of escape unless he fights and cuts his way out.

div3.head: Tuesday 18
div3.p: Last night some 18[-] men escaped from here last night, the guard snapped his gun at them and three came back Eleven more of them were catched by the dogs the rest are at large Weather has been more moderate and warm for the days.

div3.head: Wednesday, October 19, 1864.
div3.p: A lot of convalescants are sent to the Stockade this morning We have been play-ing cards and pitching pen-nys most all day to pass away the time I buy me apair of shoes pay $2.00 and then 50 cts to have them pegged I call the rool this morning

div3.head: Thursday 20
div3.p: We get a few more sweet potatoes this morning also 54 gallons syrup We hear that Richmond is taken The Doctors say it is in the papers Ed Joe Mart and I play cards nearly all day in the evening we exercise with 2 / 32. lb cannon shot,

div3.head: Friday, October 21, 1864.
div3.p: This morning we go out side to see what is for us get nothing I cut some bush for a broom Seen and I fix up our tent. I go over to Frank Hunts a while We hear no news this morning evening Weather fair

div3.head: Saturday 22
div3.p: This morning Len, Ed Joe and I go to work and fix up our tent stake it down for it is getting to be rather cold We get only 104 lbs flour to day and 40 gallons molasses but more meat than usual. I get 951 lbs. No news from the Armies. Weather cool.

div3.head: Sunday, October 23, 1864.
div3.p: This morning it is so chilly that we have to sit around the fire to keep warm I dress in my Military clothes Dr Bates offers me $20, boot to trade vests with him I get no flour to day and 39 gallons syrup. I hear that all the prisoners are to be sent here again soon

div3.head: Monday 24
div3.p: Last night was very cold for this place. the sick suffer with the cold about 30 die during the night We get no flour as yet. corn meal in place of it I buy a few plugs of tobacco from Newton play cards nearly all of the day. No news from the armies

div3.head: Tuesday, October 25, 1864.
div3.p: Newton tells me that he hears it rumored that ten thousand sick and wounded are to be exchanged at Richmond soon. Thinks it will take all who are in hospital here. Has been rather warmer to day than usual. Buy a pipe for $3

div3.head: Wednesday 26
div3.p: Rumored in camp to day that Petersburg Va has fallen Early has had another fight in the valley papers say that they have lost 60 pieces of cannon - and a large number of prisoners Weather looks like rain

div3.head: Thursday, October 27, 1864.
div3.p: This has been a cold wet rainy day the water runs through my house in a large stream I get 695 lbs flour, 460 rice and 846 of beef also 41 gallons Syrup We hear that 10,000 letters are being examined at Capt Wirz quarters

div3.head: Friday 28
div3.p: Rumors this morning say that all the well prisoners are to be sent to Millen Papers say that Gen Hood is going into Tennessee with his army Another rumor of an ex-change is going the rou nds with the patients Dr Carr is here most of the day.

div3.head: Saturday, October 29, 1864.
div3.p: New orders are out to day in regard to ishueing meat. All Hospital atten-dants must now draw their meat cooked. Beef comes in to day about noon Dr Kerr tells me that he is going to take me out side in a few days to do the Commissary Duty.

div3.head: Sunday 30
div3.p: This has been a long lonesome day nothing going on Ed and I go out side a while We hear that all the sick are going to be paro-led. Get a large lot of meat this evening I ishue ½ lb to each man in Hospital.

div3.head: Monday, October 31, 1864.
div3.p: I go out and get 7 bush-els of potatoes and one bag of red peppers. then go out and see about the bread it comes in very late I get 800 lbs of flour 224 of bacon and 594 of rice We hear no news from the Army and noth-ing from the exchange.

div3.head: Tuesday, November 1
div3.p: A lot of Convaleseants all taken from their wards and sent to the Stock- ade and another lot of sick are admitted to hos-pital. The hospital in Stockade is going to be broke up and all who are able to be sent to Millen Weather cool.

div3.head: Wednesday, November 2, 1864.
div3.p: {9}Last night it comme-nced raining and has kept up all day is cold and disagreeable and not much going on. News scarse.

div3.head: Thursday 3
div3.p: This morning Len and I go to the new Commis-sary and draw 8 bushels potatoes (sweet) Cold and rainy again stay at home and darn my stockings We get two bbls Syrup again and more than the usual quantity Flour.

div3.head: Friday, November 4, 1864.
div3.p: This morning it is very cold for the time of year it tries to rain but only mists the wind North-west. Hogan and 11 other men are paroled and came in from the Stockade We have a meeting this eve to make arrangements for election I am chosen Chairmand

div3.head: Saturday 5
div3.p: More pleasant again and quite warm during the day. I go out side to work to day feel rather tired this evening. We are now making calcu- lations to hold Election - an Tuesday next are now getting up the ticketts for McClelean and Lincoln

div3.head: Sunday, November 6, 1864.
div3.p: More pleasant this forenoon than it has been for some time but it clouds up the latter part of the day an rains some. I go to the bakery and cook house this afternoon We hear nothing about the exch-ange Commissioners meet to day

div3.head: Monday 7
div3.p: Today Len and I have been out to the commiss-ary at work all day Burns goes out with us this after noon 7 days rations come in to day - and we have a hard days work but Dance gives us a good snort of whiskey which makes us feel good Burns Bushed

div3.head: Tuesday, November 8, 1864.
div3.p: Last night we have a bonfire in the street and stump speaking several speeches are made I am chosen chairman I make a short speech Election to day 1740 votes pulled Lincoln gets 150 majority It has rained all day and we are all wet out side but nothing to wet us inside No fight-ing going on, in camp. (Cold & wet)

div3.head: Wednesday 9
div3.p: The weather has been more pleasant to day. The Confed-rates don't like the result of the election they rather would see McClellan elected here. Seem to think that the sick are all loony as the ma-jority of them voted for A. Lincoln I commence work making a set of chess men.

div3.head: Thursday, November 10, 1864.
div3.p: I go up to the Commissary this morning as soon as break-fast is over and send the flour to the bakery A lot of potatoes come in more Exchange new again The sick and wounded to be exchanged Papers say to day that Mc Clellan 40 000 Majority in New York City and a large majority in the army

div3.head: Friday 11
div3.p: I go out this morning before roll call and send the Flour and meal to the bakery. We get 11 bushels of sweet potatoes this mor-ning and a lot of greens Len stays here and gives out the bread and other rat-ions A lot of clothing comes from our lines for the [-] all go from the Stockade

div3.head: Saturday, November 12, 1864.
div3.p: I am outside this morni-ng before seven oclock have considerable work to do to day I burst one barrel of Syrup tak-ing it out of the wagon, have 100 bushels of potatoes come in carry them all in the cellar I buy me a pair of boots pay $10 ten Dollars for them in our money. More news of an exchange

div3.head: Sunday 13
div3.p: This morning I go out and do the mornings work but our Darky do not come with the cart to take potatoes to Hospital, and we don't get any to day. A limited amount of Sanitary clothing has come from our lines consis- ting of Pants Drawers socks [-] and blankets I write to Jennie to day

div3.head: Saturday 19
div3.p: More excitement to day about the Yankees raid towards Macon some say that a battle was fought Last night a train loaded with Wounded went down to day They are packing up Hospital. Stores and I prepare to Skedaddle at the first approach.

div3.head: Sunday, November 20, 1864.
div3.p: The news to day says that Sherman has passed by Macon leaving it at his right and that he is marching toward Savannah some think he will release the prisoners at Milan hope he may weather rather wet and drizzley I have a fine joke played on me by tending Mrs Hunts baby

div3.head: Monday 21
div3.p: This has been ration day have got in for 9 days it has been some work to do for one. We hear that our advance fired into Macon at two oclock this morning Dance is still packing up his traps rather think they will have to leave here Rainy cold this morning

div3.head: Tuesday, November 22, 1864.
div3.p: I have not done much work to day it has been the coldest day we have had as yet we don't hear much news to day about Sherman but think he is all right I get noisy about noon by drinking punch sleep most of the after noon

div3.head: Wednesday 23
div3.p: Last night the ground froze quite hard and it pinches one up very much Len and I commence to put a chimney in our tent Reported to day that She-rman is captured 1900 priso-ners and 17 pieces artillery don't see the capture. Juliaett 25 years old to day

div3.head: Thursday, November 24, 1864.
div3.p: This morning Bob Allen and myself commence to put up a log house for Frank Hunt we get it up and covered have worked hard most of the day News from Shermans Army scarse. A report here in Camp that the prisoners at Millan have been paroled and sent to our lines Don't believe it.

div3.head: Friday 25
div3.p: Not as cold as the past three days have been at work at Franks house most of the day Dance sends the bread here now to have it baked News from Sherman to day says he is at Griswoldville and fortifying Troops pass over the Road said to be going to Savannah Battery [-] marching orders

div3.head: Saturday, November 26, 1864.
div3.p: We hear nothing new about Sherman movements to day only that they have had a brush at Griswoldville. they say that they whipped Sherman and they think that they will soon capture him weather more pleasant we finish Franks house.

div3.head: Sunday 27
div3.p: This morning I don't feel verry well eat to many persimmons last night I go over to the Depot and see Easlick hear that our scouts were seen within four miles from here Just one year ago to day I was cap-tured how long yet must I stay in this Confederacy

div3.head: Monday, November 28, 1864.
div3.p: We hear no news to day in regard to Shermans movements we hear that we have a fleet of transports at Savannah Gen Hooker in command thought to be 50000 troops aboard. Some think we will be paroled soon one year ago to day I went into Richmond. Weather warm

div3.head: Tuesday 29
div3.p: This morning one of the guard shoots one of the pa-tients for asking him for a chew tobacco. I dream of home last night I see Maria kiss her and have a good time but it is all vanity No news to day. Weather warm for time of year. Finish Fra-nks house this forenoon

div3.head: Wednesday, November 30, 1864.
div3.p: I stay in hospital all day Len goes out and does the work and so the ishueing to Divis it has been a verry warm day have worn my vest wrong side out all day. I have a tailor rip up my overcoat to make Sack coat

div3.head: Tuesday, December 1
div3.p: This the first day of win-ter and it is verry warm and pleasant seems verry much like spring We hear nothing said in regard to Shermans movements only that he destroys every thing in his march Dr Dillard raises a muss about the meat Receive 8 days rations

div3.head: Friday, December 2, 1864.
div3.p: We hear that Gen Butler is now Secretary of War I hardly believe it a rumor also has it that the Sick are all to be paroled if an exchange cant be affected we hear so much news that I hardly believe any that I hear the weather verry ple-asant.

div3.head: Saturday 3
div3.p: The paper of to day says that the Confederate forces have had a fight with She-rman claim to have whip-ed him and taken 2000 pr-isoners Dr Eiland gets back he says the Sick at Savannah have been exchanged and thinks we will be soon Rainy this evening

div3.head: Sunday, December 4, 1864.
div3.p: I go over to the Depot but hear no news only the Federal prisoners are to be paroled soon hope it may be so Sitzer fin-ishes my coat to day no paper to be got and the Rebels say nothing about Sherman only he will go to Savann

div3.head: Monday 5
div3.p: This has been a long lonesome day nothing going on and no news from any quarter I work all the forenoon in aranging supplies in Commissary we get on some vinegar and soap New regulation in the Divisons 3rd Div's now is composed of Convalescants Weather cool.

div3.head: Tuesday, December 6, 1864.
div3.p: No special news about an exchange the paper speaks about paroling the prisoners at Savannah also that Hood and Thomas have had a heavy battle loss heavy on both sides claim they have taken 600 prisoners Dr Kerr starts for Tennesee The boys serenade me with guittar Rainy this afternoon

div3.head: Wednesday 7
div3.p: This has been another long lone-some day no news of interest Dr Thornburg says that the Confed-erate government has concluded to put the negro in the field Weather to day is changeable part of the time sunny rainy and windy and cloolar than the last few days past. Not much work to day.

div3.head: Thursday, December 8, 1864.
div3.p: Tuller is up and gets brea-kfast at 5 oclock this mo-rning I have to go out at sun rise as it is ration day get in for 7 days ful rather tired this evening Dance give len and I a house in the Camp think we will move next week Weather fine

div3.head: Friday 9
div3.p: This has been a cold dis-agreeable day wind north-east. Rains this afternoon not much work to do. No news as yet from She-rmans Army we hear that Hood lost 7 Generals in his fight with Thomas and 6000 prisoners the Rebels claim a victory

div3.head: Saturday, December 10, 1864.
div3.p: Len and I go and put a floor in our house think we can move in about Tuesday I hear to day that Sherman is within 30 miles of Savannah The rebs thinks he will go through without any serious opposition Negro Jack gets 51 lashes for telling lies about Mrs Hunt

div3.head: Sunday 11
div3.p: I go over to the upper cook house a while to see limber Jim. Then up to Head Quarters and cut up the meat for tomorrow. It is verry cold to day but pleasant. No news to day from the Armys but it is rumor that Hood has captured Nashville Tenn

div3.head: Monday, December 12, 1864.
div3.p: Len and I both go out this morning to attend to the rations. One of the reb. now has to be here to see that it is equally ishued to the Divisions. We do some work at the house but it is so cold we cant do much I hear that Gen Sherman has cut the central RR

div3.head: Tuesday 13
div3.p: Still cold as Greenland the rebels are all shiver-ing over their fires most of them with Yankee overco-ats We finish the House to day it is now ready to move in think we Shall move tomorrow We hear an- other rumor about paroling the prisoners

div3.head: Wednesday, December 14, 1864.
div3.p: This has been verry much like a spring day has grown warm verry fast all day. The blew birds are singing and it almost makes me home sick Len and I move out side to day we have a fine cabin like it verry much we have plenty of company this evening

div3.head: Thursday 15
div3.p: This is ration day again but we don't get all that is due us expect 12000 bu meal tomorrow. I hurt my back this morning it is verry lame this evening [-] news from the Army some talk about an exchange the particulars I have not heard.

div3.head: Friday, December 16, 1864.
div3.p: Not much to do the first part of the day only to serve the rations to Hospital and to the carpenters after dinner we get our din-ner we take in 7000 lbs meal We hear that Hood and Thomas have had a battle at Franklin

div3.head: Saturday 17
div3.p: To day we have not had much to do but ishue rations to Hospital and workman news is that Sherman has taken Savan-nah and the papers say that Mobiel is threatened by a raid from Baton Roushe Weather still fine no exchange news

div3.head: Sunday, December 18, 1864.
div3.p: This has been truly a long lonesom day have been read-ing most of the time only go to the Hospital and then for dinner Fuller gives us some splendid roast beef. no news from Sherman. The cow chokes on a potatoe help relieve her now ten oclock PM. J E A Six years ago to night of what are you thinking

div3.head: Monday 19
div3.p: Nothing going on to day of any importance and no news from the Army rumor has it that the names of those whose times are not out all to have their na-mes taken down and then ex-changed. I hardly believe it I finish reading a book entitled the Star and the Crown or the Daughters love. tries to rain

div3.head: Tuesday, December 20, 1864.
div3.p: This has been rather of a cold wet disagreeable day not rained verry hard but enough to make it lonesome The paper of to day says that Gen Sherman has taken Fort Mc Alister and the garrison and states that he can take Savannah without much opposition from Confederate forces

div3.head: Wednesday 21
div3.p: Last night rained verry hard but to day no rain but verry hard wind and has grown cold verry fast the rafters blown down on three of the buildings in course of construction we get three barrels of whiskey and one keg of brandy this afternoon Capt Wirz gets high

div3.head: Thursday, December 22, 1864.
div3.p: When we get up this mor-ning it is verry cold every thing frozen wind blowing hard nothing going no news from Sherman Papers say that Hood is on the retreat Thomas pursueing has cap-tured 1000 prisoners and 16 pieces artillery I cut up two hogs this evening.

div3.head: Friday 23
div3.p: This morning Len and I pack the two hogs and have cut the meat for sausage Mrs Robertson & Hunt have been busy making cake for Chris- tmas We get 3500 lbs Flour this afternoon 1000 of the old pris-oners have returned back to the Stockade We hear that the authorities are exchanging at Charleston at the rate of 1000 per day more pleasant

div3.head: Saturday, December 24, 1864.
div3.p: This has been rather more pleasant not as cold as yesterday Len and I do all of our work up to day so that tomorrow we shall have nothing to do. A part of the Artillery comes back to day some of the boys have to move out of their shantys. I expect to move

div3.head: Sunday 25
div3.p: Christmas morning not so pleasant as yesterday I write a letter to Mother Hamblin this morning there is nothing going on here to day Fuller gives us roast Beef and warm bisc-uit for dinner J.E.A. do you remember what you told me six years ago to night, Rain

div3.head: Monday, December 26, 1864.
div3.p: This morning the Battery boys come back and 400 prisoners with them Len and I have to give up our house to the original owne rs We move back to the Hos-pital untill we can build another house or untill the we can build on. We hear that Stevenson has been relieved from Duty here

div3.head: Tuesday 27
div3.p: This morning we go out and do up our work and cut some beef and mix with pork Saus-age. This afternoon we have been building us a chimney expect to move in a day or two. I hear that Jeff Davis has gone to Europe if so the Confederacy is nearly played Killpatrick reported to be at Thomas-ville

div3.head: Wednesday, December 28, 1864.
div3.p: To day Len and I have been at work building a chimney and fire place as we are got to move out side again We hear it rumored around that Jeff Davis and two of his Gen-erals have gone to Europe to turn over the Confederacy to the English Government Weather cold

div3.head: Thursday 29
div3.p: We finish up our chi-mney this fore noon it is a cold job a lot of Confederates are tight Len and I move again this afternoon Dance says we must move Capt Wirz takes our passes away from us cold and clammy News none

div3.head: Friday, December 30, 1864.
div3.p: We have not done much of any kind of work only to atte-nd to the rations We build our chimney rather higher to make more draught and put the flie over the tent Dance has slept in here most of the afternoon Papers of to day say that Hood was badly whipped in Tenn. We now do our own cooking. Cool winds

div3.head: Saturday 31
div3.p: This fore noon I go down to Hospital get shaved and wash up Len and I cut some wood to last over Sunday rains a verry little We get one load of Meal from Commissary send to Hospital I must now close my Diary and close my chapter for 1864. Wm. H. Smith.

div3.head: Friday, January 1, 1864.
div3.p: On the evening of Nov 7th/64 the Prisoners of CSA Prison Hospital Andersonville [--] a meeting for the discussion of the opp-osing candidates for the Officer of President of the US the insuing four [-] having first obtain-ned permission from Capt H King, Commandg Prison to hold such an election in Canp. Mr H K Smith was carried to the chair other officers due to existing circumstances were ignored. The [-] was [-] by singing the national anthem Columbia the Gem of the Ocean conducted by Mr [--] Merrill after which Dr [--] Hays Mounted the rostrum

div3.head: Saturday, January 2, 1864.
div3.p: and edified the meeting with an able address. He held that the finest Administration having sworn on entering upon its duties to carry out the laws and Constitution of the U.S. had been faithful to its oath, Acting wisely and just in every emergency. He considered the [-] of Gen Mc Clellan to the Union very doubtful owing to his conduct after the Battle of Antietam and his intercourse and association with such traitors and copperheads as [--]{13}

div3.head: Sunday, January 3, 1864.
div3.p: the character of Gen Mc Clellan for trustfulness and faithfulness to his country and to the cause for which he had fought. Mr Rider then made a very animated speech he was loudly applauded the consiseness of his arguments, and [-] of his conclusions, having a telling effect on his hearers. Mr Delany replied to Mr R in a very tierce manner

div4.head: Sunday, January 1st 1865
div4.p: The first day of the new year has been rather cold but a verry pleasant day have done nothing but send the rations to the Hospital and see to weighing one load that is sent from the Depot. No news from the Army. Have wrote a letter to Mother Hayden but wish I could have been with her think I should enjoy myself better than I have here.

div4.head: Tuesday 2nd/65
div4.p:
I was up verry early this morning and got breakfast so as to be ready for the rations as we are expecting 10 days rations have waited all the forenoon and none came until two oclock this afternoon and then
only a small quantity I then sent to Hospital the rations for to day except meat we have drawn none since the 31st Dec. Have been cut down on the rations flower to ¼ lb and Meat ¾ lb for a working man the flour for the sick. No news of any kind today

div4.head: Tuesday Jan 3rd 1865
div4.p: This morning We get in three load of rations I then go over to the Depot to see Capt Wirz find 150 prisoners have just arived from Albany Ga they look verry bad many of them are sick. I write a note to Reid in the Stockade Reported this evening that Gen Hood is killed his army this side of the Tenn river

div4.head: Wednesday Jan 7th/65
div4.p: This has been most a spleen-did day have not had but very little to do Len and I buy a few Sweet potatoes have a mess for Dinner. This afternoon Mrs Hunt and I go over to Mr Smiths I carry the baby have a verry pleasant visit have an introduction to two young Ladies. Get into an argument with a Confederate Soldier home on furlough he gets excited.. the most of the Negroes leave here to day This evening have had a paper speaks of Col Mulfords going to Richmond to arrange a new cartel for the exchange of prisoners hope it may prove successful and we soon be exchanged This is a full Moon light evening

div4.head: Thursday Jan 5th/65
div4.p: This morning I go to the Sto-ckade to see some of the boys who have been on the tramp saw Timberlake Craig Wag Clark and Lysles are all look-ing verry well. Capt Wirz gives me a pass to go to Hospital have been down there all the afternoon playing ball. We get old Beef for rations it is verry nice no news from the front.

div4.head: Friday Jan 6th 1864
div4.p: Len gets up this morning at five oclock and gets breakfast so that we eat by candle light. we get our work done up and then I cut some wood. The Hos-pital has been consolidated into one division We hear no news to day. Darkey Ned tries to make love to [-] she turns him off

div4.head: Satturday January 7th/65
div4.p: This has been rather cooler than the past day or two Reported that Gen Joe Johnson has again taken command of the Army of the tenn with Hd Qtrs at Macon we hear also that a Union meeting has been held at Savannah, also that the Exchange Question has got before our Congress

div4.head: Sunday Jan 8th 1865
div4.p: Not much work to do to day get through in verry good season change my cloths and Ed Darling and myself take a stroll through the country we first go to Mr Smiths visit a while with Miss June then to Mr Simes then home paper says that green bucks are par in Savannah

div4.head: Monday Jan 9th/65
div4.p: I go down to the Hospital this morning stay all the forenoon take dinner with Fuller. The patients want me to come back to the Hospital and issue the rations to them. rumored that Sherman is moving on Branchville S.C. I have a petition drawn up trying to get a Furlough for (90) Ninety days to go to my home in the State of Michigan. Rainy & windy

div4.head: Tuesday Jan 10th/65f
div4.p: Rainy most of the forenoon and windy not much work going on I go down to the Hospital this afternoon and get some bread Len gets a camp kettle to cook with I get my petition started Dr Clayton signs it and forward to Capt Wirz

div4.head: Wednesday Jan 11th/65
div4.p: This has been a verry fine day but not as warm as yes-tardy We get in rations about half that is due us Len cuts a lot of wood Mr Smiths boy Wyant is buried to day died of conges-tive chills sick only 24 hours papers state that Col Mulford and Col Child have had an interview regar-ding the exchange and are to have another soon

div4.head: Thursday Jan 12th 1865
div4.p: The remainder of the rations come this morning, in the afternoon I go over to the work house the boys are all talking about my going home have heard nothing from my petition to day. This evening a grand Military Ball is give at the depot.

div4.head: Friday Jan 13th/65
div4.p: Last night at midnight Dance comes home in a weaving way I give him some vinegar and he goes to bead. Have been down to Hospital this afternoon I get my boots caped pay $5 for it and $4.50 for the leather Some news to day about the Exchange of prison-ers Weather fine.

I woke up this morning with a verry bad head ache have done no work during the day Feel very much like having the ague. Have read most of the time finish Cowpers poetical works Not as pleasant as yestardy and weather colder. Play chess this evening

div4.head: Sunday Jan 15th 1865
div4.p: Got up this morning feeling much better than yes-tardy go over to Mr Smiths a while then over to the Cook house. Len gives us warm buiscuit for dinner This evening I spend down at Frank Hunts A.K. Smith comes up here to see me about my going home

div4.head: Monday January 16th /65
div4.p: Have not had much to do, except attend to the rations go down to the Hospital to see the boys Joe Stevens comes out here with me. Len is offered $500 in confederate money for my watch it is to Hunts being cleaned think I shall sell it Tripp makes love to a black woman Frank Hunt and I watch them

div4.head: Tuesday January 17th/65
div4.p: We commence to bother Tripp and Margaret the first thing this morning about their making love to each other last night Have not had much to do go down to Hospital and rove around the country some. Len and I cut some wood this evening after dark weather verry fine Get a new cupboard

div4.head: Wednesday Jan 18th/65
div4.p: Len and I are up early this morning and got our breakfast, and do up our work I go down to Hospital this afternoon also help the Sawyers cut some logs for shingles Paper to day says that Fort Fisher and Garrison was captured the 15th Inst verry warm to day

div4.head: Thursday January 19th/65
div4.p: No change in camp every thing about as usual some news in the papers regar-ding recognition by Eng-land and France but we Yankees don't believe the report. Think by the report that the Government is afraid that Sherman will capture Charleston unless Hardee gets reinforcements Rainy

div4.head: Friday January 20th/65
div4.p: This has been a nasty rainy day nothing to do I go down to Hospital stay an hour or two Joe Stevens is sent in the Stockade also about 50 more attend-ants Sergt Gish reports that Joe is a speculator Hunt has been plaiting a chain for me to day I write a note to Diffenbocher

div4.head: Sattarday Jan 21st /65
