div4.p: Has been rainy most of the day not much going on We get in a part of the rations expect to get in eleven days rations don't get in rations to Hospital untill near night I borrow a paper of Dance to read this evening no news in it Tennessee has gone back into the Union Brownlow nomi-nated for Govenor,

div4.head: Sunday January 22nd/65
div4.p: We get in some of the meal due for the next ten days rains most of the forenoon so we cannot work Play chess this afternoon Col O Neil of the C.S. Army getting recruits from the Stockade (Federal Prisoners)

div4.head: Monday January 23rd /65
div4.p: Has been a cloudy cold disagreeable day we get a few hundred pounds of meal some flour and peas. Col Oneal gets 150 men out of the Stockade to join the Confederate Army Some of them I am well acquainted with They do it to keep from starving to death They look verry bad 500 new prisoners from Tenn

div4.head: Tuesday Jan 24th 1865
div4.p: I go down to the Hospital this morning and stay the forenoon. Len sends our cloths down work there is none to do. We put up another barrel of beer Robertson goes over to the Depot and gets tight Dance goes to a [--] Weather pleasant

div4.head: Wednesday Jan 25th/65
div4.p: This has been a verry cold day nothing new going on no news of consequence The Drs all raising the devel about the rations issued to Hospital. I have to send in Atten-dants rations separate from the Patients Mrs Hunt goes out in the country visiting I stay with Frank tonight

div4.head: Thursday Jan 26th
div4.p: Weather still cold and windy. The paper speaks of Shermans as moving on Augusta. I go over to Capt Wirz office for a pass don't see him We get in some fresh port for Hospital Dr Ray gets a letter from Merrill

div4.head: Friday January 27th/65
div4.p: Weather still cold and not much going on I have had a splendid talk and visit with an exchanged Confed-erate soldier who was con-fined at Fort Delaware. No news in the papers to day of any importance I write a letter to Sister Jennie this evening as a mail is to leave here for the North next Monday Saturday Jan 28th/65 Not as cold to day as yes-tarday nothing of importance going on no news in the papers of note only they are harping about peace commissioners being sent to Richmond to confere with Jeff. Davis I buy a pint of sorghum whiskey this evening pay $5.00 for it

div4.head: Sunday Jan 29th/65
div4.p: This has been a verry fine day like September in the North 40 prisoners come here all Officers they are put in Castle read I go over to the Depot and also to see Sergt Weir I receive orders to day to report to Colu-mbia S.C. to start next Wednesday I don't want to go but expect I shall have to go Joe Stevens is out of the Stockade I give him my overcoat & a bottle of Syrup also $20, he says it is bad living in Stockade This evening Len goes to church and home with a confeder- ate Soldiers Wife Hide with Miss Molly Smith. Good news in the paper to day commi-ssioners sent to Washington

div4.head: Monday, January 30th/65
div4.p: Blue Monday again no news and no papers I go down to Hospital this morning the boys don't want me to go to Columbia Hunt Hide and myself go over to Smiths this afternoon have a good visit. This evening we go to church verry few in and not much of a sermon

div4.head: Tuesday January 31st/65
div4.p: This morning after I get through with the rations I have to be examined to see if I am able to stand the journey up to S Carolina I play off rheumatism on them but it don't work Len gets off without going I go down to the Stockade to see Joe play chess this evening with Waller

div4.head: Wednesday Feb 1st/65
div4.p: I wash up in good season this morning don't do any work Hyde and I get a pass and go in the Stockade to see the boys find them all doing verry well I get Joe Detailed he is coming out tomorrow The boys are feeling verry bad to have me go away and leave them This afternoon we go over to see Mo Smith folks and bid them good bye Mrs S gives us a fine piece of boiled ham. After I get home I help len awhile I burst a barrel of Syrup and he Bakes us some buiscuit to take on the march with us I spend the evening with Mrs Hunt it is a fine moonlight night.

div4.head: Thursday Feb 2nd 1865
div4.p: This morning it is pack up and be off. Shake hands and bid all good bye. Go aboard of the cars at 9 o clock leave at ten don't run verry far at Fort Valley find lots of ladies at the Depot with refresh-ments for Soldiers on their way to Augusta from Hoods Army arrive at Macon 5 PM stay here all night

div4.head: Friday Feb 3rd 65
div4.p: Start this morning at 7 A.M. pass through Gri-ffin burned by Sherman The R.R. also destroyed Gordon also was burnt. Find that the Soldiers don't want to fight Sherman Stop at Midway and pitch tents

div4.head: Satturday Feb 4th/65
div4.p: Rainy this morning start on our way at 7 A.M. reach Milledgeville at 9 A few Fortifications around the city. The city not a verry beautiful one the State house a poor one. Traces of Shermans Army all visable along the road

div4.head: Sunday Feb 5th 1865
div4.p: Don't start verry early this morning the roads are verry bad stop and rest at Sparta see some verry fine looking Ladies they hate the Yan-kees especially the Yan-kee Negroes we have ma-rched 20 miles to day see many Confederate Soldiers going home on Furlough

div4.head: Monday Feb 6th/65
div4.p: Start early this morning for Mayfield arrive there at 9 o clock don't get abo-ard of the cars until 4 P.M. Some few Ladies here at the Depot no accomod-ations for them Sherman reported within 15 miles of Branchville Start at Sundown run verry slow the road verry ruff.

div4.head: Tuesday Feb 7th 1865
div4.p: This morning all at a place called Camak leave at 12 pm for Washington Ga cant go by way of Augusta as Sherm-an has Branchville We now have to march to Abbeville S.C. draw one days rations I go up town get apple jack at $3 per drink some of the ladies in town send us refreshments

div4.head: Wednesday Feb 8th/65
div4.p: No news this morning we go up town Hyde and I pass by the residence of Gen Robt Toombs formally U.S. Senator have a social glass with a Dr Hyde a fine old Gentleman Bill Warren comes in camp on his way to Columbus.

div4.head: Thursday Feb 9th 1865
div4.p: Leave Washington this morning have only one wagon to carry our baggage have to carry our knapsacks the ground froze stop for the night at Danberg 9 miles from the Savannah river cold night but clear and moonlight

div4.head: Friday Feb 10th 1865
div4.p: Start at sunrise cold and road ruff cross the Savannah river in a flat boat at Lisburg the Broad River connects with it here also cross a small river called Little River cross in a skiff. have marched 20 miles to day encamp at 8 o clock 8 miles march and then we reach the R Road Warmer this evening.

div4.head: Satturday Feb 11th/65
div4.p: Resume our march about 9 o clock a fine morning for Feb arrive at Abbeville at ele-ven o'clock to fine town the Ladies think we should be guarded encamp near the Depot we draw 4 days rat-ions here a colord woman cooks my bread for me get some washing done here

div4.head: Sunday Feb 12th/65
div4.p: Go up town this morn-ing get to argueing about the war with two ladies they are bitter rebels and down on old Abe. They wish Sher-man in some bad place but don't say where another lady sends me down some buiscuit and fresh pork Nothing from Shermans army to day Our Darkies have had plenty of their Colord friends down to see them

div4.head: Monday Feb 13th/65
div4.p: Good bye to Abbeville and its people start at 8 o'clock run verry slow road ruff pass through some verry fine towns Newbury for one Darky girls selling Cakes along the road encamp at Austen near Broad River a cold night

div4.head: Tuesday Feb. 14th/65
div4.p: Eat our breakfast and start for Wynsborro to take the cars for Columbia arrive there at dark 21 miles march are wet cold and hungry Five of us go into a saloon to get something to drink and loos the rest of the boys Go into a house to enquire the Lady gives us a good warm supper Her name is Huntington

div4.head: Wednesday Feb 15th/65
div4.p: Find the boys this morning quartered in the market house I furnish Hyde & Atwater with ½ pint of rum draw three days rations here a negro woman cooks ours Sherman reported to be within six miles of Columbia and having a heavy battle people here are scared expect him here soon

div4.head: Thursday, Feb 16th/65
div4.p: An exciting day to the citizens of Winnsberro they are afraid of Sherman and many of them are leaving the town Columbia surrendered at 8 o'clock this morning creates a panic here a heard battle yestardy the Confederates loose heavily All aboard of the cars at 2 P.M. and start for Charlott No. Ca. I see Dr White he tells me we are to go to Saulsburry for Exchange arrive at Charlott at 10 P.M.

div4.head: Friday Feb. 17th/65
div4.p: Every thing in a bustle here go up town see Col. Farns he says we are to be exch-anged. go to the Hotel & get my supper No news from Columbia to day.

div4.head: Satturday Feb 18th /65
div4.p: Start this morning for Saulsburry all the talk now is about the exchange reach the city and go into the Stockade we are told we shall not stay in long. put up our tent I pay $5 for poles and pins the prisoners here look better than at Andersonville. Some are drawing Clothing.

div4.head: Sunday Feb 19th/65
div4.p: Get ½ loaf corn bread & a small piece of meat for a days ration We are taken out about 10 o'clock they say we are going home stay at the Depot waiting for transfer ration we get most devilish hungry I buy some ginger cakes A train load of Off-icers pass through here on their way for Exchange

div4.head: Monday Feb 20th/65
div4.p: We hear that we may have to wait a week for trans-portation draw one days rations consists of 1 pt flour and ¼ pork Hyde meets with a friend he gives him a quantity of Onions Cabage pork Sausage and pie. Shermans Army rep-orted moving on Charlotte, N. C.

div4.head: Tuesday Feb 21st/65
div4.p: Left Saulesburry last night at 7 P.M. Now at Greenville 50 miles from Saulsburry we go where choose to when the cars stop have a hard time sleeping the car is so crowded No rations since leaving Saulsburry cold riding top of the cars

div4.head: Wednesday Feb 22nd/65
div4.p: Arrive at Raleigh at day lig-ht find a train load of Offi-cers here cant get to Willm-ington as the Armys are fight-ing Hatch goes down to see the Gen Commanding draw two days rations here the Off-icers buy $700 worth of prov-isions and give it to the sick men we are sent into Camp 4 miles from the City

div4.head: Monday Thursday Feb 23rd/65
div4.p: Still in Camp we are busy cooking our rations Bush and I play chess to pass away the time citizens come in camp to buy spec-ie A few Ladies come in camp Selling pies and cakes Hear nothing when we shall get away from here.

div4.head: Friday Feb 24th/65
div4.p: No news when we shall leave this camp we go around Camp where we choose Clouds up and rains The Maj Commanding sends me down after my parole did not get it get up about 10 o'clock and draw rations get meal and pork

div4.head: Satturday Feb 25th/65.
div4.p: A cold wet day cut wood and keep a large fire to keep warm pay $2 for the use of an ax for an hour Some of the boys feel rather down the mouth & think we are to be fooled Pack up at 5 o clock and start for Golsburro reach there about midnight, stay in the car all night 60 men in each.

div4.head: Sunday Feb 26th/65
div4.p: March to Camp this morning get 2 days rations of beef and meal Beans find one of our men in the road nearly dead. dies in ½ hour from the time of finding him bury him in my blanket don't know what he belongs to nor his name we are paroled in squads of 50 Take the cars about 8 o'clock

div4.head: Monday Feb 27th 1865
div4.p: This morning finds us within 7 miles of our lines all in good spirits about going home the rebs don't pay mu-ch attention to us they are satisfied we shall not run away reach the truce ground at 12 o'clock verry few Of-ficers are there reach the ground held by our forces at 2 P.M. Every body Cheers

div4.head: Tuesday Feb 28th/65
div4.p: We march 8 miles last night and go into Camp draw Crackers and a dram of whiskey This morning we reach Wilmington are quarted in old barracs a cold wet day and all of us hungry and waiting for rations Take a stroll down town.

div4.head: Wednesday March 1st /65
div4.p: All are busy this morning drawing rations recieve 4 days. Our Officers come in about noon they are nearly as destitute as the privates One boat load of prisoners go away to day Weather verry damp and disagreeable. Go up town find Wilmington a very fine place

div4.head: Thursday March 2nd/64
div4.p: Go up to the Soldiers retrea to see the Officers find Maj Bogle one load of them leaves to day 6 boat load of Negro troops come up the River weather damp 300 of us go aboard of the steam propeller Frances shove out in the river and drop anchor make my bead side of the smoke stack.

div4.head: Friday March 3rd/65
div4.p: On our way at 9 o'clock rains verry little a pleas-ant trip down as far as Fort fisher the anchor is let down and we are all crowded on the deck to see the fort it is a strong earthwork Two years ago this day I left home.

div4.head: Saturday, March 4th/65
div4.p: Still in the river wai-ting for the wind to go down so we can go to see the breakers roll and the Captain says we cant get over the bar Rations of crackers Bacon coffee & shugar are issued to us this morning Old Abe takes his seat for an-other 4 years term.

div4.head: Sunday March 5th/65
div4.p: Verry ruff this morni-ng the old boat rolls like a log. no word when we shall leave Cold and we are obl-iged to keep below the Captain goes ash-ore to see when we shall go to sea all anxious to be off

div4.head: Monday March 6th/65
div4.p: Up early get our brea-kfast cook coffee in the furnace in the eng-ine room they tell us we shall start tomorrow the boys all mad becau-se we don't go all are anxious some are singing and some cursing

div4.head: Tuesday March 7th/65
div4.p: A good wash and then get my breakfast. The Capt goes ashore and gets rations and a supply of water the order comes to start get under way about 3 o'clock rather ruff the boys get sea-sick our boat rolls nearly on her beam ends as she has no ballast in her

div4.head: Wednesday March 8th/65
div4.p: Lay abead most of the time to day don't go on deck until after dark clouds up and rains pass Cape Hateras about five o'clock not as ruff here as we expected to have it Solon gets sea sick I have stood it like a brick so far.

div4.head: Thursday March 9th/65
div4.p: Verry Foggy this morning the Captain is lost and don't know where he is expects we are in Ches-apeake bay clears up at 9 o'clock we are 10 miles out of our way reach Fort Monroe at 5 P.M. stay here two hours two English men of war at anchor.

div4.head: Friday March 10th/65
div4.p: Cold and windy have to keep between decks to keep warm Arrive at Annapolis about noon mustered for our Comuta-tion money and draw a complete outfit of cloths 10 o'clock at night the col-dest night I have seen since leaving Anderson-ville.

div4.head: Saturday March 11th/65
div4.p: Feel rather dull get no sleep last night get our certificates for Comutation receive it in the afternoon I get $114,50. take the cars at 4 o'clock for Camp Chase Ohio take the Baltimore and Ohio R.R. stop at the relay house A verry Ruff country.

div4.head: Sunday March 12th/65
div4.p: This morning find we are at Berlin below Harpers Ferry. The Ferry a small town noted for the John Brown Insurrection. One of the men falls from the cars and gets his legs mangled he dies from his injuries ride top the cars most of the day

div4.head: Monday March 13th/65
div4.p: This morning we are at Grafton stop here nearly an hour get a glass of ale here. The Country very mou-ntainous pass through several tunnels on the R.Road, reach the Ohio River about 8 P.M Ferry acrost at Bellair & go aboard of the Cars

div4.head: Tuesday March 14th/65
div4.p: Find ourselves at Barnes Villre on the Central O-hio R.R. run off the track 2 miles below town 11 Cars of the track two upset two men hurt, takes all day to straitened up buy me a hat pay 4 Dollars for it start on our way at 8 o'clock raining some through the night

div4.head: Wednesday March 15th /65
div4.p: This Morning we are at Ganesville Hide and I go up town I send a letter to Mother Hamblins This is a fine town stay here until noon More peddlers here than than soldiers some of the boys gets drunk I drink some ale start at noon reach Columbus at 5 P.M.

div4.head: Thursday March 16th/65
div4.p: Wet and rainy this morni-ng hear nothing when we shall get away from here I sent a note to Chas A. Tabor also one to Sistr Jennie find two bys here that used to belong to my Regiment grows cold this afternoon

div4.head: Friday March 17th/65
div4.p: The Clerks are busy ma-king out the Furloughs and discharges for the Ohio troops to day some of them get their two months pay and stole away this afternoon The work goes on verry slow don't expect that I can get transporta-tion before next week This is St. Patricks day Jubilee with the [-]

div3.head: Saturday, February 20, 1864.
div3.p: {14}Clear & pleasant Came in from Picket this forenoon. Were Muster-ed into the Veteran Service for three years 2nd enlistment

div4.head: Satturday March 18th/65
div4.p: A lot of Ohio troops go out to day Hyde goes up to the State House to see about his being mustard out. Indiana troops are now on the docket Michigan comes next I go to the office and try to get transport- tation so that I can to night but I must wa-it until the Michigan men are called for think we will come about morning The Camp here is full of sharpers with every thing to sell

div3.head: Sunday, February 21, 1864.
div3.p: Inspection of Camp by General Birney & Staff & of Arms & Accoutrements by an officer of General Wards Staff The day verry pleasant

div4.head: Sunday March 19th/65
div4.p: Liet Fisher and I get passed out and go up town I find C A Taber stay with him until 12 0'clock I then go to Simontons Hotel and stay the remainder of the night. Come back to Camp about 9 A.M. the Michigan troops are called for at noon I give in my name, hope to get away tomorrow. Hyde leaves for home we change barracks. A fine day

div3.head: Monday, February 22, 1864.
div3.p: Anniversary of Washington's Birthday. Cloudy and Cool.

div4.head: Monday March 20th/65
div4.p: Cold and clear this morning the remain-ing lot of Michigan men are called in this morning and are mus-tered 7 of us men whose time is out get trans-portation for Detroit We leave at 240 P.M. stop at Grafton at 8 reach Toledo in the night.

div4.head: Tuesday March 21st/65
div4.p: This morning I go down to Uncle Jonathans and see them start for Hills-dale at 12,30 reach there at 7 P.M. find my fol-ks all well except Jims wife she is sick abed I surprise all the folk

div3.head: Tuesday, February 23, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & Pleasant Cos K & C drilled together in Skirmish Drill 29 more men were Mustered to Serve for three more years a part of the Regt those not reinlising received pay to day for the months of Nov & December. 63

div4.head: Wednesday March 22
div4.p: I go over to Mrs Tom Pkinses and take dinn-er find them all well find a number of my old acquaintances to day this evening att-end a party at Waldron Hall it goes off verry ni-ce. take supper at the Western Hall $2 I also go up and see Mary Finch she is worrying about Joe

div3.head: Wednesday, February 24, 1864.
div3.p: Companies C. & K drilled as yesterday weather fine five more men were mustered this fore noon. Had a Review of the 3rd Corps in the afternoon by Genl French the day was all that could be desired for such an event It was the grandest specticle of the kind I ever witnessed There was a great number of Lady Spectators{15}

div4.head: Thursday March 23rd
div4.p: I go up to Johns to day to see the folks take dinner there one of his boys sick this afternoon I call on Marion Hew-itt and Mrs Alice Wren. Jenett Anne's comes in town she says that Emaline is Marri- ed Cold and windy

div3.head: Thursday, February 25, 1864.
div3.p: Some what Cloudy & windy No drill to day Mailed a letter Home to day Had a Severe Wind Storm just after dark. Took a Note for 24 dollars an Robert Stoddard & payable to J G Reynolds loaned [-] Reames, 1.00 & Lev five dollars

div4.head: Friday March 24th/65
div4.p: I do a verry little visiting to day it is so cold that I stay in the house and visit with Aunt Ma-rion I also go over to Cousin Jameses his wife not so well to day has more fever This evening I call on Elsie Dillon and Hannah Baldwin I take the cars at 1,15 for Detroit

div3.head: Friday, February 26, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear and Cool Had orders about noon to Releive the pickets of the 6th Corps. that Corps being ordered on a recon-aissance Our entire Regt & our line was from the Hazle to the Rappahannock Rivers

div4.head: Saturday March 25
div4.p: I go to the adjutants Office this morning to see about being mu-stered out he send me to the general mustering Officer I get my Discharge pay and bounty bef-ore noon I receive $387.30 cts stay in the city over night a splendid city it is

div3.head: Saturday, February 27, 1864.
div3.p: A Beautiful clear day Nothing occurred during the day worthy of Note About 11 P.M. a detail of the 2nd division of the 3rd Corps arrived & relieved 3 Cos of our Regt those relieved were sent to the Reserve where we remained the balance of the Night

div4.head: Sunday March 26
div4.p: I walk about the City some John Farly and I stop to gether A public meeting is held at Camp and Matins

div3.head: Sunday, February 28, 1864.
div3.p: The remainder of the 2nd Division who had straggled came up to relieve the ballance of our Regt by 10 A.M. We then started for Camp which we reached about 2 P.M. Had about an hour to get dinner draw Rations and then Marched on to rejoin our Division which Started at 5 A.M. to the support of the 6th Corps passed through Culpepper which was once a beautiful Town Marched Moderately; halted about 8 P.M. within four miles of James City where Made about 8 miles, bivouacked in a Pine Grove for the night

div4.head: Monday March 27th/65
div4.p: Start for Sagineau this morning reach there at 4 P.M. find Jennie well and looking for me Visit until eleven when I go to bed

div3.head: Monday, February 29, 1864.
div3.p: Revilie at 4 A.M. Were under way at 5 Marched the Brigade & Division at 8 ½ A.M. at James City. Were Mustered for two months as soon as halted. All quiet until 2 P.M. when Cannonading was heard a good distance to our front Supposed to be our Cavalry ad-vance. The 6th Corps are at Cedar Mountain Several miles

div4.head: Tuesday March 28
div4.p: This morning I go and buy me a suit of cloths scarf & pin for which I pay $5. I find Wallace Burton and have a visit with him look around the town a large amount of Buisness done here Wesley keeps a splen- did Hotel

div3.head: Tuesday, March 1, 1864.
div3.p: All quiet during the day Commenced raining at Dark Our mess had erected a good Shed of boards procured from an old Barn in the Neighbor= hood that made us a Comfort=able protection from the Storm It also occasioned us Consid=erable Sport by pulling down over us twice during the night heard Cannonading about 11 A.M. raining all day slowly then Commenced Snowing rapidly late in the Evening & Snowed until 9 P.M. Then turned to freezing

div4.head: Wednesday March 29th
div4.p: This morning I go over to Saginaw City and sit for a Photograph Cant get them until Satturday next. Jennie will send them down to Chitenango weat-her cloudy and looks like rain

div3.head: Wednesday, 2, 1864.March
div3.p: Revilie at 5 A.M. and orders to move at 6 ½ A.M. The Morning clear & bright The ground covered with snow & considerably frozen. At the hour named we Started back to our Camp the object of the Reconnoisance having been accomplished arriived at Our Camp at 20 minutes past 1 P.M. Had a muddy march I was much fatiqued

div4.head: Thursday March 30th
div4.p: This morning John Smith carrys me down to the Salt works. Jennie puts me up some refre-shments to eat on the cars. I start at 10,15 reach Detroit at 6 P.M. go to the Theatre in the evening a splendid peice Start for Hillsdale at 11 15 P.M.

div3.head: Thursday, March 3, 1864.
div3.p: A brignt warm day All was bustle to day in getting ready to Start Home to morrow At 4 P.M. the Regt. Was for=med & marched first to Genl Birneys Head quarters, then to Genl Wards to take leave before Starting Home. We are to leave at 5 to morrow Morning

div4.head: Friday March 31st/65
div4.p: I arrive at Hillsdale at 7 A.M. go to Cous-in Janes and get breakfast then go up town and sit for a half Dozen pictures at Andrews go over to Tompkins and stay over night have a fine visit This evening I attend a party at Mary Finches

div3.head: Friday, March 4, 1864.
div3.p: Cool & Somewhat Cloudy Revilie at 3 A.M. Started from Camp at five, took Cars at Brandy Station at Seven Arrived at Washing-ton City at 2 ¼ Bought a History of the Pinens-ula Campain. Paid a Short visit to the Capitol got Supper at a Restaurant & returned to quarters

div4.head: Saturday April 1st
div4.p: Have run around town most of the time to day go to Tompkins es and stay again to night I buy me a pair of boots pay $9,00

div3.head: Saturday, March 5, 1864.
div3.p: Indications of Rain Wind from S.E. Commenced to rain at 10 A.M. Visited the Smith=Sonian Institute. The pay-Master Commenced to pay the Veterans of our Regt at 12 M. after being paid purchased some Clothing an Album ½ a dozen Photographs Left Washington at 5 P.M. arrived at Baltimore at 11 P.M. I did not Sleep any until after 3 A.M.

div4.head: Sunday April 2nd/65
div4.p: This has been a verry fine day Have visited at Jims all day Luther Jim & I go and have a walk down the R.R. Go to Church this evening to the Methodist Church

div3.head: Sunday, March 6, 1864.
div3.p: Left Baltimore at 6 A.M. the day was Cloudy & Cold passed Harrisburg at 2 P.M. took Supper at Mad=ison Pa

div4.head: Monday April 3rd/65
div4.p: Go up town this mor-ning{16} and get one of my pictures have my water fixed an sit around until Dinner time This afternoon Jule and I go over to Mr Fairfields make a short call Reported by Telegraph that Richmond is give up I think it is a sensation Report.

div3.head: Monday, March 7, 1864.
div3.p: Arrived at Pittsburgh Pa at 6 A.M. Morning dark & Chilly took breakfast at the Mansion House 50 cts. Good Sun broke out at 9 left the City at 10 Had more drunk men on board then I ever Seen at one time passed Crestline at 11 P.M.

div4.head: Tuesday April 4th/65
div4.p: Last night about 8 o,clock the Court House and church bells are ring cannon fired and a lar-ge bonfire built selebrating the capture of Rich- mond James and his folks here go over east and saw wood I visit at James to day Emeline & Husband come up on the train also Jenette I take Jenette and Leila to Wold-rans hall to the tableaus this evening

div3.head: Tuesday, March 8, 1864.
div3.p: Arrived at Union City at day break. Morning Clear & frosty. Arrived at Muncie Ind at 8 A.M. twelve inclu-ding myself took breakfast (Free of Charge) at a Citizens House. Train left before we could get back. We followed an hour later on the Night Express A beautiful day Went to Theatre at Night.

div4.head: Wednesday April 5th 65
div4.p: Get up at 5 o,clock this morning and start for Toledo at six - get there at 9 A.M. visit with Un-cle Jonathans family to day Aunt lib and I have a walk up Summit St in the evening. her girl Jennie Leuackenbush is sick. Jonathan wants to sell out and go to the oil regions of Penna

div3.head: Wednesday, March 9, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & Cool the Reception of our Regt which was to have taken place to day was deferred until to Morrow on account of the absence of the Governor Took a room at the Commercial Home for the Night. Met Brother Walker Who Came by the 5,40 train from Lafayette

div4.head: Thursday April 6th/65
div4.p: Up this morning at 7 Jonathans folks don't know that I have gone leave Toledo at 7,50 have had a fine time to day made good time Now 9 P.M. waiting in Buffalo for the train for Syracuse is raining verry hard expect to get home tom-orrow if I have good luck

div3.head: Thursday, March 10, 1864.
div3.p: Still in the City Morning Cloudy & Damp Cannons were fired at Sunrise at a Signal from the Ladies to pre=pare dinner for the Reg which formed at the Rendervous near the west end of Washington Street Marched the entire length of the Street & back to Soldiers Home where we partook of a Sumptous dinner after which we marc-hed again to the east end of Washington St & back to the State House where we were welcomed by the Governor in an appropriate Spirit we were also addressed by Genl Milroy Cols Colgrove & Taylor after which we marched to the Arse=Nal & deposited our arms Many of the Boys left for Home this Evening. Went to the Theatre to night with Walker

div3.head: Friday, March 11, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy & Cool Started Home on the 11,40 train got to Lafayette at 3 ½ P.M. left from Delphi at 6 P.M. arrived at Home about 8 found all well

div4.head: Friday April 7th/65
div4.p: This morning finds me in Syracuse take break fast at the Globe Hotel look around the city during the morning take the cars at 7 ½ P.M. for Chittenango arrive there at 8 find some of my old acquaintances in town go down to Mothers this evening find her well stay there this even-ing Aunt Dolly comes down to see me

div3.head: Saturday, March 12, 1864.
div3.p: Forenoon Clear & Warm Saw & Conversed With Many old acquaintances Went to Delphi in after noon to see about the Co bounty bought a Hat for Willie

div4.head: Satturday April 8th
div4.p: After Breakfast I go up town see James Ma-rshall send my trunk up by him ride up to Mr Hamblins with G, Blakeslee they are look-ing for me I find all well but Louisa she is complaining of a cold and sore throat I have a fine visit home looks natural as ever Little Joe gone home.

div3.head: Sunday, March 13, 1864.
div3.p: Raining this morning Stormed all day Snowing Some in the Evening & freezing, at home all day

div4.head: Sunday April 9
div4.p: After Breakfast I black my boots and wash up for the day set around the house the most of the time Write a letter to Frank Beverstock this after noon

div4.head: Sunday April 9th/65
div4.p: Stay in the house and visit the most of the time to day rains a par t of the time to day Mother Ham-blin has the rheumatism in one arm.

div3.head: Monday, March 14, 1864.
div3.p: Left Home for Mothers by Way of Logansfort at 6 A.M. Arrived at Burnetts-vile at 10 ½ A.M. The day Cloudy & Cool Snowing at intervals all day. Stopped at Uncle McCormicks for night

div4.head: Monday April 10th/65
div4.p: This morning Father and I go to Perryville with a grist see some of the citizens in the afternoon we go to Chittenango to do some trading get some clover seed see a paper Gen Lee has Surrendered his Army to Gen Grant yestardy Salutes are being fired in every city.

div3.head: Tuesday, March 15, 1864.
div3.p: Ground Covered with Snow tho morning Clear & Cool. Father Mills arrived about 11 A.M in a Buggy to take us to Mothers. Started at 1 ½ P.M. Stopped at Uncle John Steele's a short time Got to Mothers an hour before Sundown.

div4.head: Tuesday April 11th
div4.p: {17}This morning I [-] rails to build a fence acrost the old field also three loads of stone This afternoon I go up to Erasteses and Perryville take tea at Decon Smiths this evening I write a letter to Hillsdale

div3.head: Wednesday, March 16, 1864.
div3.p: Still verry Cold & Cloudy at Mothers all day. Had an invitation to a dance at Mr Milers this Evening to which we went & Remained until 9 P.M. Seen Several old acquaintances Mother made me a present of a nice pr Socks

div3.head: Thursday, March 17, 1864.
div3.p: Still Cloudy & Cold. Assisted Mr Mills Some in putting a fence around the Yard, but was in doors most of the day after-noon quite pleasant.

div3.head: Friday, March 18, 1864.
div3.p: Stormy Snow & Windy a verry disagreeable day left Mothers at 9 A.M. for Monticello. Took dinner at Mr Conches. Took Cars for Logansfort at 6.30 P.M. from Logansfort we came to Delphi & Walked Home to Pittsburgh But did not get Home as we could not Raise the ferry man Stopped for the Night at Mr [-]

div3.head: Saturday, March 19, 1864.
div3.p: Came Home early this mor=ning Still Windy & Cold got a letter from Hoover this Morning. Went to Delphi in the Evening & Received my County bounty 150 dolls in two Notes of 75 dolls each payable in one & two years with 6 per Cent interest. Cashed one at Dugans at 10 per cent discount Loaned Walker 20 dolls & paid an account of 20 dolls at Farichild.

div3.head: Sunday, March 20, 1864.
div3.p: A verry rough day. Snowing Rapidly at times & blew hard all day attended Divine Service at 2 ½ P.M. at the Methodist Church after Service went Abner Crowders not having been to see them Since at Home in 63. thirteen months Since.

div3.head: Monday, March 21, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & Bright prospects of a pleasant day walked to Pittsburgh in the fore noon & back to Mr Crowders from there we went to Hirhers in the afternoon to Spend the Evening until bedtime. This day was more pleasant than any for a week past After we got Home I went for Doctor Angele for Mrs Thompson's little Boy

div3.head: Tuesday, March 22, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & frosty Went to Delphi this fore-noon in Company with Bliss & Turner to get their Co Bounty. Bought Cloth for Pants for Willie. Brought Home a lot of Engravings & Photographs which I had or-dered from New York assisted at a washing filled an Album. Lifted a Note at Cottons of 7 dollar Spent the Evening at Home

div3.head: Wednesday, March 23, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & more moderate indications of rain Paid a bill of two Dollars to Dr Angele. Spent the afternoon & Evening at Walkers Evening quite pleasant

div3.head: Thursday, March 24, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear Moderate Went to Crowders this fore noon to engage a team to draw wood. Took Dinner there & put a Circular Saw in order & returned Afternoon verry warm

div3.head: Friday, March 25, 1864.
div3.p: Sleeting & raining this morning rained Slowly the early part of the forenoon The day has been Cloudy & damp but little rain has fallen. I have been engaged in Copying my Dairy which has been kept in pencil in another Book to this.

div3.head: Saturday, March 26, 1864.
div3.p: Morning dark & foggy & warm. Fog lifted about 9 A.M. the Remander of the day was Clear & warm Bought a bushel of apples Went to Delphi in the after-noon. Wrote a letter to Mr Snyder Monticello & Sent by J.C. B Joseph came down in the Evening & is with us for the night.

div3.head: Sunday, March 27, 1864.
div3.p: Morning balmy & Mild appearance of rain but cleared up by 9 A.M. the rema=inder of the delightful went to Sabbath S chool at one P.M. & to preaching after preaching went to Mr Crowders to Stay over Night

div3.head: Monday, March 28, 1864.
div3.p: Morning windy & Cloudy Came Home from Crowders early this Morning having got His team for the purpose of drawing wood Drew 4 loads by noon when it commenced raining & Stopped further opper=ations , in the evening I went to Delphi in Company with James Hoover to procure His bounty. He & Lady took Sup=per with us

div3.head: Tuesday, March 29, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy & Somewhat Cooler than last Evening. Took Mr Hoover & Lady to Delphi this morning to take Cars for Wabash town. Cashed a Co bond at Dugans this morning & returned by 8 A.M. paid Dr Morrow 10 Dollars for Medical Services Since in the Service & [-] a Note of 18 dolls to Charles Baum to Mother Baum

div3.head: Wednesday, March 30, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Cool Brother Joseph Started for Home this Morning Myself Mary & Mother Baum Started on a visit to Grandmothers and Uncle David Baums took dinner with Grandmother & went from there to Uncles in the Evening to stay all night rained consider-able after dark

div3.head: Thursday, March 31, 1864.
div3.p: Still Cloudy but more pleas-ant than yesterday Left Uncles about 10 A.M took dinner at Cousin John Baums in Delphi gave Mr Jones a Call & Mr Green also left Delphi for Home about 5 P.M. Spent a verry agreeable day Received word after my arrival Home of My Mothers Sickness Word having Come that She was verry ill and reques=ted us all to come & see her as soon as possible

div3.head: Friday, April 1, 1864.
div3.p: A Bright Warm morning until about 9 A.M. when it began to cloud up & get cold. Started in Company with Abner Crowder to Mothers about 8 A.M. took Dinner at Mrs. Warpells on Kings Creek & arrived at Mothers at 2 P.M. found her verry sick The evening was verry cold for the 1st of Apr

div3.head: Saturday, April 2, 1864.
div3.p: More pleasant than Yester=day. Mother Seemed much better than last Evening Started for Home at ½ past 10 A.M. And arrived at Home at 5 P.M. Was much fatiqued Evening warm with indications of rain

div3.head: Sunday, April 3, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Bright & Warm Mary & Myself went to Delphi to Church (quarter meeting) Attended love=feast. United with the Methodist Church by letter took dinner at Mr Youngs went to Sabbath=School attended the afternoon service. From 3 P.M it began to cloud up & turn cooler Heard Mr Jones preach at Pittsburgh at night

div3.head: Monday, April 4, 1864.
div3.p: Commenced to blow & rain before day & continued to rain until noon. I Sat as Clerk on an election Board to day Did not rain in the after=noon. Was detained on the board until about 6 P.M. commenced to rain some at dark. Robert Mc Beth came to stay all night with us.

div3.head: Tuesday, April 5, 1864.
div3.p: Morning dark, Misty & Cool. Was not engaged in anything particular to day Cut Some wood for Walker family this morning Rode a Colt to Abner Crowder's this Evening & back. John & Z.I. Baum arrived this Evening Heard through them that Mother was no better on Sabbath Evening

div3.head: Wednesday, April 6, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Cool the early part of the day. Paid Mr Fairchild 6 dollars in full of all account to this date. Rode to George Spices Contracted for 12 loads of wood paid 15 dollars on the Contract & Came Home by Noon Sun Shining by Noon But soon Clouded over again Recieved payment of a on my Brother of 96.22 & paid a like amount to Snyder of Monticello on Note

div3.head: Tuesday, April 7, 1864.
div3.p: Dark & Cloudy Wind from the South Sun come out by 9 A.M. & the remainder of the day was clear & warm. Abner's fami-ly came in on a visit to day I used his team to finish draw=ing wood Credited 5.50 on a Note of Crowders payable to me

div3.head: Friday, April 8, 1864.
div3.p: Warm & cloudy this morning commenced to rain quite early raining about Constantly all day bought some refuse lumber for Pig Sty bought a shank of Veal in the Morning & a half a doz Mack=eral in the evening. Father Mills Came down to stay over night with us heard that Mother was much better likely to recover evening verry wet

div3.head: Saturday, April 9, 1864.
div3.p: Sun arose verry bright & warm this morning comm.-enced to rain about Sunrise had a beautiful Rainbow - Drive Madges Mules to Delphi this morning to Mill Was back by 9 A.M. built a pig sty took a Note of Crowder for $51.05 payable one day after date. Bought a barrel of Salt at Lane's. Myself & family went to Crowders to spend the night

div3.head: Sunday, April 10, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Wet & quite Cool re-=mained at Mr Crowders until after dinner Came in for Church at 2 ½ P.M. Stayed in for Class Meeting. Heard Mr Post a Baptist Minister preach at 4 ½ a good cool Sermon Still dark &.]

div3.head: Monday, April 11, 1864.
div3.p: Heavy Mist this Morning cleared off by 8 A.M. Continued warm Clear until 4 P.M. when it Clouded over & began to rain Was engaged in doing turns to day Sent to Delphi & bought ham bought eggs Sold a Steel Plate Engraving to Mr Isaac Mills for 1.00

div3.head: Tuesday, April 12, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & Cool this Morning but became more pleasant as the day advanced. Were at Uncle Dan Baums for dinner Went to Delphi in the evening bought an oil Cloth Came Home Cousin Robert & Brother Walker took Supper with us took a Severe pain in my Side just at dark applied a Mustard poltice which gave some relief

div3.head: Wednesday, April 13, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & quite Cool. pain in my side very Severe yet Had pleasant Showers of rain & Hail during the day. Bought Stationary at Fairchilds also a bushel of Potatoes for seed Add Baum left for Cal-ifornia this morning Joseph left for Indian=apolis this morning I should have gone had I been able

div3.head: Thursday, April 14, 1864.
div3.p: Sun was bright & red but was obscured by Clouds almo=st immediately. Left Home for the army at 8 A.M in Com=pany with Mother Baum & brother Walker the former came to Stockwell & the later to Lafayette got to Indianapo=lis at 6 P.M. the day was partly clear & cool

div3.head: Friday, April 15, 1864.
div3.p: Still Cloudy & Cool Stopt at Nationals Hotel lodging 75 Reported at Camp Carrington at 9 A.M. was detailed as [-] for the day Left for Home at 10-40 P.M. Came as far as Lafayette, and lay over until Morning

div3.head: Saturday, April 16, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cold ground frozen quite hard arrived at Home about 8 A.M. Fred Shields took breakfast with me Found my Family well A.W Crowder took dinner with us. Was out most of the after=noon to witness the Home-=Guards drill Uncle John Steele & Robt. Mc Beth took Supper with us Evening very Cool.

div3.head: Sunday, April 17,1864.
div3.p: Morning clear & Beautiful Mary & I took a walk to the graveyard Early in the fore=noon. Abner & Amelia were in to See me before I Should leave. Attended di=vine twice in the afternoon. Spent an hour or two at Brother Walkers in the Evening. Robert Mc Beth Mrs & Miss Parker were in to See us late in the Evening

div3.head: Monday, April 18, 1864.
div3.p: Damp & Cool having rained some during the Night left Home at 8 A.M. for Indianapolis to rejoin my Regt" Arrived at 5 ½ P.M. Stopped at the National House

div3.head: Tuesday, April 19, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & Cool orders to leave for Washington by 12 M Sent my Overcoat Home by Express this morning Recieved my ration money five dollars Left Indianapolis at 1 P.M. on the Bell[-] Road the day so far was delightful Arrived at Muncie about 5 P.M. Where the Citizens brought us a bountiful Supper to the depot the same place also displayed great liberality as we went Home taking us to their houses & giving us excel=ent breakfast. On this occasi-on they entertained us while waiting by the Ladies Sing=ing some fine songs

div3.head: Wednesday, April 20, 1864.
div3.p: Arrived at Marion Ohio at Sunrise Changed Cars at Crestline arrived at Pittsburgh Penn at 9 P.M. Where we took Supper at the City Hall after which we took Cars immediately & Started East at about 11 P.M.

div3.head: Thursday, April 21, 1864.
div3.p: Arrived at the Great tun=nel just at Sunrise the Morning was verry Cool there being Considerable Snow on the highest el=evations of the Mountains changed Locomotive at Altoona Pa got Breakfast lay one hour This is the 4th time I have passed over this Splendid Road & I have been more than ever impressed with the Majesty of Gods works as displayed in the works of Nature. the day was the most beautiful that Could be desired for a trip over this magnificent Route arrived at Baltimore at 10 ½ P.M. where we took Supper & stopped for the night

div3.head: Friday, April 22, 1864.
div3.p: The Morning Clear and pleasant. Took breakfast at a Restaurant. Got a Shave before taking Cars for Washington at 12 M. arrived at Washington City at 4 P.M. where we are awaiting further trans=portation. Wrote a letter to my Wife at Baltimore appearance of rain this Eve-=ning

div3.head: Saturday, April 23, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & Warm the after=noon quite windy. Did not leave Washington until 3 P.M. Drew Clothing before Starting Marched from the Soldiers rest to the 6th Street Wharf Where we took Steamer for Alexandria I was detailed as guard with the baggage & was not relieved until 11 P.M.

div3.head: Sunday, April 24, 1864.
div3.p: A Clear warm day. Wrote a letter Home this morning. The Regt left Alexandria for the front a 7 A.M. I was left in Charge of baggage & did not leave until 11 A.M. Arrived at Brandy Station Va at 6 P.M. & proceeded at once to Camp about 2 Miles distant

div3.head: Wednesday, April 27, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & Cool Had Regimental Inspection at 8 A.M by which time the day was quite Hot - Had Company drill forenoon Batallion drill afternoon & dress Parade in the evening grew quite Cool late in the Evening but Some rain about dark Had Regimental Inspection at 8 A.M.

div3.head: Thursday, April 28, 1864.
div3.p: Sun arose clear with Cold wind from the N. E. Continued Cool all day; The Companies were exercised in the Skirmish drill forenoon & the Battallion in field Evolutions in the afternoon grew much Col-der late in the evening With Cold North wind

div3.head: Friday, April 29, 1864.
div3.p: Clear with a Smart frost the night having been verry Cold. Afternoon quite hot. Company drill forenoon & Division Drill on Division Parade grounds about 2 Miles from Camp by division Genl" Birney Did not get back to quar=ters till near Sundown. Attended a prayer meeting in Camp to night.

div3.head: Saturday, April 30, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & hazy but quite Cool Had general=Muster for 2 Months pay & a fifty dollar installment of Bounty. Did Not drill any to day this day being set apart by a general order for the pur=pose of Washing Clothes was verry windy towards Evening & rained Some.

div3.head: Sunday, May 1, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & Warmer than for Some days past Had Inspection at 9 ½ A.M. Wrote a letter to my wife in the forenoon, were marched out to a Dagaurean Gallery to have a likeness on negitive of the Regt but after wating a while& the day becoming late we were ordered back after which we had divine Services on the Calvn-line by the Chaplain & a prayer meeting after dark

div3.head: Monday, May 2, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & pleasant in the morning & most of the day Co drill forenoon. Battallion formed for drill in the after=noon But were recalled with=out drill Had a violent wind storm about 4 P.M. & continued to rain until after dark.

div3.head: Tuesday, May 3, 1864.
div3.p: Cool & Clear Had Company drill forenoon & Inspection by an officer of Genl {18}Wards Staff received orders to mar=ch at `11 Oclock to night Recieved a letter from Home this Evening the 1st I have recieved since I left Broke Camp at 11 P.M. Marc=hed all night. Stopp The assem=bling of our division at Such an hour of the night on a level plain east of our camp Without any noise not even the sound of a bugle was a grand im=pressive grand scene

div3.head: Wednesday, May 4, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & warm Stopped about 7 A.M to get Coffee about 1 ½ miles of Germa=nia ford on the Rapidan Crossed over to the South side of that stream at 10 ½ A.M. from then we went direct to the Chancellorville House where one year ago yesterday was fought one of the most sanguinary Battles of modern time. Passing over this bloody field brought vividly to mind many of the startling & tragic scenes there enacted. We arrived here at 2 P.M & Bivouaced for the night.

div3.head: Thursday, May 5, 1864.
div3.p: Were up before day light and under way by sunrise after going east about one m we turned Square to the right going to the west one mile we came to the Welford Home where one year ago the 2nd of this month and where our Division was entirely cut off from the remainder of the army & stole through their lines under cover of the dark the family were at Home & a beautiful Lady was out in the yard in front of the House one of our men remarked to her that he had been at her Home about a year ago "was you she replied God give you strength for the present." She tried to look pleasant but there was every indi-cation of fear & alarm in her countenance

div3.head: Friday, May 6, 1864.
div3.p: The battle which comm.-enced at 2 P.M. was renew-ed by us as early as Sunrise The Enemy were driven near a mile. When a new columen of the enemy coming upon us we were compelled it turn to fall back just at this juncture I was wounded & became a prisoner Was wounded on the top of the head & in the left Shoulder

div3.head: Saturday, May 7, 1864.
div3.p: Was in the enemies lines all day was treated verry kindly I am compelled to form a better opinion of those men since amo=ng them

div3.head: Sunday, May 8, 1864.
div3.p: To day we are still in the Same place the day is pleas-ant my Shoulder is considerably painful the ball still remaining in it I convers- ed with Several verry intelli-gent men to day including to Chaplins

div3.head: Monday, May 9, 1864.
div3.p: Some thunder & Showers of rain to the north & West early in the day after wards it became verry pleas=sant. Had my wound ban-daged this evening for the first time Heard considerable Cannonading east of us in the evening

div3.head: Tuesday, May 10, 1864.
div3.p: Still in the Same place Morning Clear & pleasant Heard Cannonading quite early in the day more distant than yesterday, which was incessant during the afternoon I am tolerable Comfortable my wounds are not much painful I have experienced Some hunger to day I should feel much dejected but I have found relief in prayer & in an iplicit Confidence in Gods love & protecting Care

div3.head: Wednesday, May 11, 1864.
div3.p: Today was Cloudy & Windy Commenced to rain about 2 P.M. & was showery the rem=ainder of the evening & mo =st of the Night. Heard Canno-nading all day in an Eeastyin direction Most of the Surgeons & wounded men of the Confederates have left leaving barely enough to Cook for & wait upon our wounded men

div3.head: Thursday, May 12, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Cool this morning heard verry heavy Cannona-ding as early as day break which continued without Cessation until 9 A.M. at which time it Commenced raining rap=idly this is the 8th day since the battle Commenced & it seems as if Heaven has to weep over the scence The Surgeon in Charge took the ball out of my Shoulder this evening a pretty Severe opperation. He is much of a Gentleman & seems to be verry desirous of alleviating our Sufferings as much as possible His Name is Bolton

div3.head: Friday, May 13, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Showery all day & quite Cool in the afternoon. About 14 of our men Started afoot for Orange C.H. this morning distance 20 miles. We were also visited by a Flag of truce in the forenoon for the purpose of procuring the body of Genl" Wadsworth who died at this Hospital 4 or 5 May the Company consisted of a Capt Surgeon, A Staff Officer, & a Cavalry man bearing the flag an army waggon drawn by horses with the driver there was no fighting to day only a few artillery reports in the afternoon I have been quite comfortable to day & am Still the recipient of the best of treatment at the hands of the men who have the Care of me

div3.head: Saturday, May 14, 1864.
div3.p: Pleasant Showers with gusts of wind heard considerable Cannonading to day but could not learn any thing definite as to the results I was quite unwell to day had fever & Chills all day perhaps Caused by the gathering of matter in my wound

div3.head: Sunday, May 15, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Showery all day 21 of us (6 federals priso=ners) & 15 (wounded Con-federates) left the field Hospital in the Wilderness near Chancellorsville about 10 A.M & marched about 10 miles to a Village Called Madarievile Where we Stopped in a Vacated house for the Night We were caught in a heavy thunder Storm I never Suffered as much any Sabbath before if I had not found relief in prayer My case would have been one of gloom & despair

div3.head: Monday, May 16, 1864.
div3.p: Left our place of lodging about Sunrise & made Orange C. H. about 1 OClock here we were brought some bread butter & Milk which revived us greatly we then waited an hour or so & took Cars for Gordons=ville where we arrived about 4 P.M. Had our wounds dressed & were lodged in the Hospital

div3.head: Tuesday, May 17, 1864.
div3.p: Still Cloudy & damp with frequent light Sho=wers I had quite a Chill early in the day follow=ed by a high fever which lasted until in the night & was followed by a verry debilitating night Sweat There was an arrival of Federal prisoners at this place between 12 & one OClock over 1400 in number Some 400 of them have left to night for Linchburg

div3.head: Wednesday, May 18, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & bright I feel verry unwell & verry weak this morning My wound Seem to be doing well however & I trust I Shall soon be better could not go to breakfast this morning did not have anything until noon when it was brought to me commenced raining about 3 P.M. & did not Stop until about Sundown

div3.head: Thursday, May 19, 1864.
div3.p: Clear all day the first in two weeks Was much better to day than Yester=day I did not have any Chill Yesterday. But my wounds & the exposure I have undergone have ma=de a marked Change in my appearance, although they seem to be doing well this evening a train load of troops of Breckenridges Corp passed over the Va" Central R R to join Lee a large arrival of wounded Confederate Soldiers Came in here to night & were distributed through the different Wards

div3.head: Friday, May 20, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & pleasant this mor=ning. There was 4 trains of Soldiers passed through here early going towards Richmond No news but there Seems to be a great concentration of Lees for=ces preparatory to another battle. R R Communication has been temporarily Sus=pended between here & Richmond upon one or two occasions Since my arrival here

div3.head: Saturday, May 21, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & Warm all day They were many Lady Visitors about the Hosp=ital but I suppose the Color of my clothes precludes any possibility of my having any conversation with any of them Just after Noon we were ordered to have our things in readi=ness to leave as the Cars would be along soon but from some Cause they did not arrive & we are still here to night. My Shoulder is verry painful from some Cause this evening

div3.head: Sunday, May 22, 1864.
div3.p: Morning balmy & pleasant My Shoulder is Still pain=ful & I Could rest but little during the night I Read Pauls Epistles to the Thesselonians this morning. There was another train load of Con- federate Soldiers of (Breckinridges Corps) passed this place this morning for Richmond Left Gordonsville this P.M. at about 2 OClock for Linchburg Va" distant 80 Miles Where we arrived at Sundown. There were 223 Conf-ederates & Federals all Sick and wounded 21 of the later including 9 of our Commiss=ioned Officers from Colonels down all wounded

Morning Clear with a Cool bracing atmosphere I enjoy =ed a verry good nights rest & feel quite comfortable this mor=ning got my clean Shirt this morning but I begin to feel the want of a proper amount of food. Read Pauls Epistles 2nd to Timothy Titus & Philemon Wrote a letter Home to day had a transient visit from a couple of Ladies the first that have Shown themselv=es

Clear & quite warm forenoon I feel quit well & my wounds Seem to be doing well. Two Officers of our Squad were Sent away to the City prison. We had a heavy thunder Storm in the afternoon heavy rain. Read the two Epistles to Thesselonians & 1st Timothy today. Sent out a Shirt & pair of drawers by a colored woman to have them washed

After having breadfast we were removed from the Hospital where we Stopped last (it being only a recieving Hospital) to Cromptons Hospital about ½ Mile up in town where we had our wounds dressed for the first time Since we left Gordonsville. We have pretty good beds here but bedbugs are numerous & bold we get but a Scanty diet rice coffee (a miserable Substitute) Corn bread & a verry Small bit of fat bacon once a day.

Morning Clear & pleasant grew warm towards noon. I was engaged to day in reading a Small Volume entitled Judalis Livn which is ind=eed interesting it was furni=shed by some Ladies for us to read I keep close to my bed as I have no Clothes to wear out. My Shoulder is Supper=ating freely but does not Seem to be healing any yet. We had quite a heavy rain in the Evening acco=mpanied by thunder and lightening & Considerable Wind

div3.head: Friday, May 27, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & Cool this morning engaged this Morning in the perusal of my book. Grew quite warm by noon but did not have any rain to day Could not get any news to day, but a telegraphe dispach going the rounds this Evening that there has been a hard fight to day near Hanover C. H. in which they Sustained heavy loss it also reported that Gordons Ville has been evacuated by the Con=federates I was quite unw=ell this evening & night

div3.head: Saturday, May 28, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear I feel verry debilitated & weak this Morning. I paid 50 cts Confederate money for an egg for breakfast Kept Close to my Cot to day Spent as much of my time as I was able in reading my book "Judaleh Livn" it rain=ed considerable to day. By the Richmond Papers we learned that a flag of truce boat Came up James River as far as City Point this gave us great hope that the letters we had Started would be Sent forward Soon I felt better by noon

div3.head: Sunday, May 29, 1864.
div3.p: Verry Cool & Clear all day I feel pretty comfortable to day read a good many Chapters in the Testaments to day And I feel much better every way than I did yester=day We were visited this eve=ning by 4 Ladies of this place who were quite Socia=ble & Seemed to manifest Considerable Sympathy for us

div3.head: Monday, May 30, 1864.
div3.p: Still Cool & Clear. My Shoulder feels quite Sore from Some cause perhaps owing to the Cool Weather. This is the 35th anni=versary of my birth. How peculiarly I am Situated to what I have ever been on such an occasion before. But thanks to a kind Providence that my life has been Spared & that I enjoy a hope of yet being restor=ed to my Family & Friends. God grant that all his mercies may incite me to live more to his honour So as thereby Secure his favor & my Souls Eternal Welfare Wrote a letter to Brother Walker

div3.head: Tuesday, May 31, 1864.
div3.p: To day was quite warm I was verry unwell to day having had a chill in the night followed by a high fever which did not abate until noon. My head is verry pain=ful to day the Glands all over my breast are Swolen My head is so painful that I Cannot rest it upon the pillow with any comfort I am verry bilious My phy-sician has not paid any attention to me for 3 days past. There was some Ladies paid us a visit this after=noon

div3.head: Wednesday, June 1, 1864.
div3.p: I am much better than yesterday although my head is Sore yet my Stomach is much out of order & my bowels are constipated. This Morning is quite pleasant.

div3.head: Thursday, June 2, 1864.
div3.p: Verry warm to day I put over a bad day very sick & weak Commen-ced to rain about the mid-dle of the afternoon & rai=ned the remainder of the Evening & all night

div3.head: Friday, June 3, 1864.
div3.p: Still raining I feel much much better to day am clear of fever but exceeding-ly weak. Ceased raining by 9 A.M. but remained Cloudy all day. I am getting truly tired of being a prisoner of war & Shall hail with more than ordinary joy the day when I Shall again be liber-ated. My wounds Still Seem to be doing well.

div3.head: Saturday, June 4, 1864.
div3.p: I have nothing to note to day more than I believe it rained pretty much all day. I was too Sick to notice anything that transpired

div3.head: Sunday, June 5, 1864.
div3.p: Sunday was clear and pleasant all day I read Some in the Testament to day Was much better than yesterday but am verry weak Do not know that anything transpired to day

div3.head: Monday, June 6, 1864.
Wednesday, June 15, 1864.
div3.p: Was Removed from the Hospital to the City prison to day. 14 of us Many of our wounds are yet in bad Condition. My own is yet running badly & verry painful at times. We were put into an upper Hall about 16 by 40 or 45 ft with only 2 Small windows in one end where there was not less than 100 men confined to Eat & Sleep.

div3.head: Sunday, June 19, 1864.
div3.p: Were removed from the Hall to another build=ing one Square east to a larger & better ventilated building where we had plenty of Room and air & access to good water There was 147 of us all told Most of them were from Hunters Command who have been threatening this place for a week past Our Situation is much bettered as regards air & room but we fare no better as to diet which is issued to us each morning at 8 AM for the Succeeding 24 hours about enough for one meal. Corn bread & pork with water is our only diet

div3.head: Wednesday, June 22, 1864.
div3.p: Were roused early this morning & ordered to get ourselves in readiness for a move. We were soon ready filed out of the prison had days rations of Corn bread & bacon passed to us then marched to the Cars were then informed that we were to go to Dan-ville Va where we arrived about 12 at night & remained on the Cars until the next mor-ning

div3.head: Thursday, June 23, 1864.
div3.p: Were taken off the Cars about 8 A.M & marched to one of the City prisons a large commodious build verry Comfortable compared with the Linchburg prisons the day was Clear & hot We did not draw any thing to eat until late in the afternoon The men suffered much hunger. We had expected to be Shipped further to-wards Georgia to da but had to remain over for want of transportation there was 1300 Sent away from here this morning for Georgia

div3.head: Friday, June 24, 1864.
div3.p: Left the prison an hour before day & procee-ded to the RR From here we had a new guard & a new Set of Officers who were very abusive tyrannical. To da we ran only 48 miles to Greensbooroo N. C Where we arrived at about 2 P.M. After dark we were put into Cars verry much crow-ded to Sleep for the night

div3.head: Saturday, June 25, 1864.
div3.p: Had to change cars again this morning & got un-der way about 8 A.M. & were all day running 100 miles. The day was excess-ively hot & being much crowded we suffered greatly did not get to our place of stopping Charlotte NC until after dark. Were immediately changed into other Cars where the dirt & vermin was near half an inch deep where we rested as best we cou-ld for the night there being over 50 men many of us wounded

div3.head: Sunday, June 26, 1864.
div3.p: Sun rise clear & hot drew Some Rations this morning. Left Charlotts-ville at 7 A.M & ran to Columbia SC where we arrived a little before Sundown Changed Cars after dark Moved out of town 2 miles & Slept in the Cars again

div3.head: Monday, June 27, 1864.
div3.p: Left before Sunrise & made 138 Miles to Augusta Ga where we arri-ved an hour by Sun We were taken off the Cars & Stopped in a nice green near plenty of water where there was a good Chance to bath & Strech our werried] limbe. To day was not so hot as thos preceeding. Here we were permitted to rest over night

div3.head: Tuesday, June 28, 1864.
div3.p: Did not leave until 3 P.M. when we emb-arked upon the Cars for our final destination running all night. We had verry heavy rain to night. We reached Macon Ga just at day light the Comm-issioned Officers who came with us were left we then went on and reached Anderson Ville about 12 Had Smart Shower this Evening

div3.head: Wednesday, June 29, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy and warm I am tolerably well But find this the most miserable place that man ever conceived of 2800 men crowded into an enclo-sure of perhaps less than 10 acres hardly Stand-ing room as about ½ of the entire lot is a Swamp from Knee to waist deep

div3.head: Friday, July 1, 1864.
div3.p: A part of the prison=ers were removed into a new Stockade inclosure of about 5 acres

div3.head: Saturday, July 2, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & hot but there was a good breece Had considerable talk of a parole of prisoners to commence the 7th inst. I took a Scale of my Skull bone from the wound on top of my head this Evening My wounds are not doing well since I came here

div3.head: Sunday, July 3, 1864.
div3.p: The morning quite pleasant a cool breeze from the S.W. Had Roll Call through all the detachments

div3.head: Monday, July 4, 1864.
div3.p: Warm & Sultry in the morning. Had Heavy Showers of rain with Lightning & thunder in afternoon. Cleared up in the evening

div3.head: Tuesday, July 5, 1864.
div3.p: Not so warm as before the rain. Had a new arrival of prisoners from Shermans Army Found 7 or 8 of the boys of the 20th Regt who were much Surprised to see me as I had been reported as dead

div3.head: Wednesday, July 6, 1864.
div3.p: Sun verry Hot but good breeze I was quite unwell to day with Diarhea Had another arrval of prisoners from the Army of the Potomac

div3.head: Thursday, July 7, 1864.
div3.p: Verry Close & Sultry in the Morning Nothing of note occurred to day

div3.head: Friday, July 8, 1864.
div3.p: Was quite unwell to day. Verry hot and threatened rain in the Evening. Another arrival of prisoners

div3.head: Saturday, July 9, 1864.
div3.p: Am much better to day. Still hot. Had a heavy rain about 4 P.M. & another arrival of over 300 pris-oners

div3.head: Sunday, July 10, 1864.
div3.p: Clear this morning with a cool breeze at times although the Sun is oppressively hot another large arrival of prisoners this Mor-ning. Read Several Chapters in Acts this Morning

div3.head: Monday, July 11, 1864.
div3.p: Another arrival of pris=oners to day. At 5 P.M. the Camp of prisoners witnessed the Execution on the gallows of 6 murder-ers & thieves who were arrested & tried by a jury of 12 of our Sergeants & Sentenced to be hung It was no doubt, justice, but it was an impressing Sight to me one that I never care to witness again

div3.head: Tuesday, July 12, 1864
div3.p: Cloudy a part of the fore noon with ind=ications of rain. Towards noon the Sun came out verry hot Another arrival of 600 prisoners to day from the Army of the Potomac

div3.head: Wednesday, July 13, 1864.
div3.p: After a good nights rest I was up early I was up early Cloudy in the morning but Soon Clea=red up Soon
The most excessive=ly hot day I have experi-enced Thunder Showers passed round in the afternoon but did not rain any of acc-ount with us

div3.head: Friday, July 15, 1864.
div3.p: Still verry hot. Showers passing round in the evening as yesterday Serjents of detachments were called out of the Stockade & informed that in case of an attempt to escape they would turn their Battery upon us & shell us as long as a man was alive. Have had a bad Diarhea to day.

div3.head: Saturday, July 16, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Cool in the Morning until 9 A.M. The remainder of the day was excessively Hot. I was verry faint & weak & the tent oppressed me much Still verry bad with Diarhea which I have had over a week

div3.head: Sunday, July 17, 1864.
div3.p: Some better to day than Several days past the day was Clear & pleasant, & I Spent it verry pleasantly reading a good por-tion of my time in the Scriptures. We drew a Ration of Molasses to day the first Sweet I have tasted Since a prisoner

div3.head: Monday, July 18, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy for the most part With Showers of rain in the Evening I was verry unwell with Diarhea to day Nothing of general importance occurred worthy of note

div3.head: Tuesday, July 19, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Clear by turns & verry warm am much better to day than yesterday Attended Religious Services after dark heard a verry good Sermon from Christs words to the impotent man at the pool "wilt thou be made whole

div3.head: Wednesday, July 20, 1864.
div3.p: To day verry hot I was verry unwell nothing of importance occurred to day, only that the Rebels Com=menced to throw up fortifications at this place it Seems they are ap=presensive of a Raid upon the place

div3.head: Thursday, July 21, 1864.
div3.p: Warm & clear, getting dry. I am feeling bet-ter to day than yester-day although I am not well

div3.head: Friday, July 22, 1864.
div3.p: Forenoon clear & hot the later part of the day Cloudy & pleas=ant. Another arrival of Prisoners near 5,00 including Some of my own Regt=

div3.head: Saturday, July 23, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & quite Cool all day. Met 3 of the Boys of my Regt" to day among them George Larkum of Co. K. Who met me like a brother, from him I learned from Him that I had been reported dead on the Co Rolls

div3.head: Sunday, July 24, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cool & pleasant a verry pleasant day throughout. Read 9 Chapters of Isiahs prophecy to day & 3 Chapters of Marks Gospel Night uncommonly Cold for this Season of the year

div3.head: Monday, July 25, 1864.
div3.p: Cool all day, was quite unwell again, but the night was not So cold as last.

div3.head: Tuesday, July 26, 1864.
div3.p: Growing warmer, Cloudy for the most part, but pleasant. Was verry un=well the forenoon, of today, but am better this Evening

div3.head: Wednesday, July 27, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing to note to day verry warm

div3.head: Thursday, July 28, 1864.
div3.p: Still verry hot. Am verry unwell to day Diarhea & fever got Some medicine this Evening Had a large arrival of prisoners from Shermans Army to day. Evening Showery

div3.head: Friday, July 29, 1864.
div3.p: Am Some better to day the medicine Seemed to have a good Effect. More pleasant than yesterday With quite a heavy Shower in the Evening another arrival of prisoners from atlanta this Evening

div3.head: Saturday, July 30, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy for the most part & pleasant. I am better of my Diarhea but my Stomach is better weak & I lack appetite am getting weak got a good mess of rice to day which was verry palatable & done me much good

div3.head: Sunday, July 31, 1864.
div3.p: A pleasant day. the Rebels were verry busy all day working on their fortifications & Slashing timber aro=und the Stockade. I was better than for Some days past.

div3.head: Monday, August 1, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy for the most part & pleasant. Some Showers in the after noon. To day a Rebel Chaplin Came into the Stockade, preached a Sermon, & informed the men that an exch-ange had been agreed upon to take place im-mediately. I was quite lame with Rheumatism to day

div3.head: Tuesday, August 2, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Cool most of the forenoon, quite a number of Sick were taken out to day, & it is thought they are to be Shipped for exchange. Time will make it all known. We await the result with no small degree of anxiety Had a Severe thunder Storm & a verry heavy rain. 430 of Stonemans Cavalry arrived here late in the Evening Captured near Macon

div3.head: Wednesday, August 3, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Bright & warm & the day light. The rebels took out about 14,00 of our Sick & wounded to the Hospitals to day. Some light Showers in the Evening. the night Cool & pleasant. No Roll Call to day

div3.head: Thursday, August 4, 1864.
div3.p: A pleasant day. No Sick were taken out of the Stockade to day alt=hough there had been an order to bring them to the gate. Finished reading the book of Isiah's Prophecy to day. No Role Call to day

div3.head: Friday, August 5, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & warm. No rain Gate opened to pass out Sick at 2 P.M. But only a Small portion of those who had been carried to the gate were taken out. My health is improving. I have Sold two buckets of bean soup to day & read 3 Chapters of Marks Gospel & 5 Chapters of the book of Proverbs.

div3.head: Saturday, August 6, 1864.
div3.p: Forenoon verry Sultry & hot Was engaged in Selling Soup on the Street to day but was quite unwell. A light Shower in the Evening a great deal of thunder & lightning at all points of the Comp=ass No roll call to day nor Sick Call a man Shot dead by one of the guards

div3.head: Sunday, August 7, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & Warm a Hot day Throughout Read 10 Chapters in the book of Proverbs. Am Suffering greatly from Soreness in the legs & Swelling of the ankles am at a loss to know what it Can be.

div3.head: Monday, August 8, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy & Sultry Commenced Selling bean Soup this morning ag=ain. Heavy rain came up by 2 P.M. which continued till near Sundown, which cooled the air & done a great amount of good

div3.head: Tuesday, August 9, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy & Cool & pleasant until 9 A.M. when it cleared & was followed by a Shower rain about noon. This was followed by another later in the afternoon one of the heav-iest I ever witnessed, which washed down the Stockade in some places & Caused quite a Stir among the rebels I was quite unwell to day

div3.head: Wednesday, August 10, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy & damp about 9 A.M. the sun Came out quite warm Had another heavy rain this after-noon, & also after night we passed a verry disagree=able night

div3.head: Thursday, August 11, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy most of the forenoon Had a light Shower about noon afternoon pleasant with pleasant night I was verry unwell to day with Diarhea & pain in Stomach

div3.head: Friday, August 12, 1864.
div3.p: Cloudy most of the fore=noon. Clear & verry hot afternoon. I am very unwell to day Diarhea & Strong Symptoms of in=flamation of the Stomach & Bowells, feet much swollen

div3.head: Saturday, August 13, 1864.
div3.p: Nothing of note to day Verry Warm a light Shower about noon

div3.head: Sunday, August 14, 1864.
div3.p: Excessively hot. no rain I was not able to attend Roll=Call to day

div3.head: Monday, August 15, 1864.
div3.p: As hot as yesterday I was verry weak & Suffered greatly with pain in my Stomach & Bowels. From 2 or 3 P.M. it Clouded over & became more pleasant I feel much better this Evening, look much like rain

div3.head: Tuesday, August 16, 1864.
div3.p: Still verry hot. No news much better. Had a Shower just at dark

div3.head: Wednesday, August 17, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear & more pleasant than for Several days past. Nothing occurred worthy of note to day

div3.head: Thursday, August 18, 1864.
div3.p: A Bright hot day. I was verry unwell to day. To day I met Sergeant Lang of the 12th Indy "Vols" from Monticello Ind" from whom I learned that Capt" Brown was not dead as I last heard but was at Home wounded & that Lieut Bartholemew was dead

div3.head: Friday, August 19, 1864.
div3.p: Still quite hot to day. I am much better than yesterday. Had a light Shower of rain about 3 P.M.

div3.head: Saturday, August 20, 1864
div3.p: Verry Warm. Rain in the evening. Was verry unwell again to day A dreary Sabbath cleared up late in the Evening. No rain during the Night

div3.head: Sunday, August 21, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy & pleasant until 10 A.M. When it began to rain & continued Showers most of the day A dreary Sabbath Cleared up late in the Evening no rain during the night

div3.head: Monday, August 22, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy & verry Sultry Cleared off by 10 [-] A.M. & was one of the hottest days I have experienced in the Confederacy No rain to day. Was verry sick in the Evening

div3.head: Tuesday, August 23, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & verry warm but more pleasant than yes=terday

div3.head: Wednesday, August 24, 1864.
div3.p: Left the tent where I have been living for Some time past & have to Sleep out in the open air from this on

div3.head: Thursday, August 25, 1864.
div3.p: Verry hot to day & am quite unwell. Nothing else worthy of Note

div3.head: Friday, August 26, 1864.
div3.p: Still verry hot feel much better than for some time past hope I Shall be better{21}

div3.head: Wednesday, August 31, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Cloudy & Cool The Summer is Ended, and there is but little prospect of our deliverance as yet but I am thankful that my health is as good as what it is. I Still hope that God in his Kind Providence may Soon See fit to bring about that Event & So Relieve the Suf=fering of thousands besides my-self, & restore them & me to their families & Friends.

div3.head: Thursday, Sept. 1, 1864.
div3.p: Morning clear & beautiful, I feel pretty well this morning for which I am truly thank=ful{22}

div3.head: Wednesday, Sept. 7, 1864.
div3.p: Clear & verry warm. The long expected exchange commenced to day. Six Detachments have left to day for the point of exchange I have been verry unwell to day Sergt Lang of Monticello done me a favor by getting me a biscuit to day

div3.head: Thursday, Sept. 15, 1864.
div3.p: Left the Stockade late this evening in hopes of being off immediat=ely but from Some Cause they were delayed & we lay only at the Depot all Night

div3.head: Friday, Sept. 16, 1864.
div3.p: Morning Clear with promise of a hot day Still at the Depot at 8 A.M.

div3.head: MEMORANDA.
div3.p: {23}Was wounded on top of the head & in left Shoulder May 6th/64 at the battle of the "Wilder-ness" & taken prisoner by the Rebels.
May 12th Surgeon Bolton of the Confederate Service (But a Gentleman) extract=ed the ball from my Shoulder, A pretty Severe opperation as I did not take Chloroform

May 15th & 16th Marched from Field Hospital at Wilder=ness to Orange C. H. A Severe trip for me Arrived at the CH at 2 P.M. from thence was transported to Gordons Ville by R.R. where we arrived about five P.M.

div3.head: MEMORANDA.
div3.p: May 22nd 1864 Left Gordons Ville in Company with 223 other Wounded Soldiers & Officers at 1 P.M. & arrived at Linchburgh Va, & rested at the recieveing Hospital of that place

June 15th Was Discha=rged from the Hospital & Sent to the City Prison where I was Confined one Week June 22nd Were Started under guard by RR for Anderson Ville Ga June 28th Arrived at Camp Sumpter the Military Prison of the Confederate States about noon of the day
